chapter.head: Introduction
chapter.p: Ethiopia has an estimated 29.5 million cattle distributed within the different agroecological zones (Sendros and Tesfaye, 1997). The arid, semi-arid and sub-humid zones are homes for 14% of the cattle population each while 6% and 52% of the cattle population inhabit the humid zones and the highlands of the country, respectively. The majority of the cattle population is found in the highlands of Ethiopia where 43.6% of the human agricultural population is residing which indicates that cattle has a very important role in the Ethiopian economy (Jahnke, 1982). A total of 800,000 tones of milk and 220,000 tones of meat are produced by cattle annually which account for 30% the agricultural products that contribute 46% of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP). Livestock also has a significant share from the export earnings (15%) (Azage and Alemu, 1997). In addition, 14 million tones of manure are used annually primarily for heating and six million oxen provide the draught power required for the cultivation of grain crops (Azage and Alemu, 1998 and Brannang and Persson, 1990).

Although the livestock sector has a significant contribution to the national economy, animal productivity is extremely low. This is evidenced by the very low per capita consumption of protein and a very low growth rate of milk and meat production that is below the recommended average rate needed to feed the growing population (Sendros and Tesfaye, 1997). With an annual growth rate of 3.5% the human population in Ethiopia will increase to about 139 million by the year 2020, therefore, the demand for animal products is estimated to increase substantially (Azage and Alemu, 1997). The low productivity is due to a number of factors among which are quantitative and qualitative deficiencies in the feed resource base, diseases, poor animal performance level and insufficient knowledge on the dynamics of the different types of farming systems existing in the country (Plaizier, 1993).

Among all factors emphasis has been given for the improvement of the genetic potential of the local breeds of cattle in the country. Over 99% of the cattle population in Ethiopia are indigenous and about 42% are milk cows (Tsehay,1997 and Azage and Alemu,1997). There are over six distinguishable, indigenous cattle types in Ethiopia evolved mainly as a results of natural selection influenced by factors like climate, altitude, available feed supply, endemic diseases, functional objectives of livestock owners, management
techniques and market demands that make them adapted to harsh environmental conditions. Most of them belong to the Zebu-type with the inclusion of some intermediate short horn Sanga type (Albero and Solomon, 1982 and Ethiopian Mapping Agency, 1981). Almost all indigenous cattle are in the hands of the small holder subsistence farmers that represent 85% of the human population (MOA, 1993). The average milk production capacity of the indigenous cow per head per lactation is estimated at 213 kg which is very low (Azage and Alemu,1997). The introduction of exotic (temperate) breeds has been suggested as one option to improve the productivity of indigenous cattle, but it has become expensive and risky because the exotic breeds are susceptible to diseases and the cost of milk production is often greater than the gross income that can be obtained. Therefore, combining the adaptability (hardiness, disease tolerance, ability to walk long distance in search of feed and water and heat tolerance) of native cattle with the high milk production potential and faster growth rates of temperate cattle through cross breeding, especially for dairy production, has been practiced as a more sustainable way to improve productivity. This has opened the door for market oriented dairy production systems with improved genotypes and better management that, however, today represent only 0.3% of the total cattle population (Tsehay,1997). Moreover, urbanization (29.2% of the total population will live in growing urban areas by 2020) and the subsequent decrease in the number of rural community will create a substantial increase in the urban demand for animal products particularly for milk (Azage and Alemu,1997). Dairy production systems which can respond to such a demand under conditions of unfavorable infrastructure are found in the peri-urban and urban areas.

Breed improvement programs for dairy production in Ethiopia were started by importing pure temperate breed of cows during the Italian occupation and since then crossbreeding using temperate breeds and indigenous breeds has been practiced by a number of governmental and non-governmental institutions. However, these efforts have been met with little success because of the various technical, organizational and socioeconomic constraints. There has been no concrete and binding breeding policy with regard to the choice of the exotic breed types to be crossed with the indigenous animals and the corresponding exotic blood level of the crosses (Tesfaye, 1990). In addition, most of the breeding programs had no clearly defined breeding objectives and in almost all of the production systems performance recording has been difficult. Alemu et al. (1993) indicated that performance recording procedures in some eastern and southern African countries has
been insufficient and unstandardized. They have further stressed that such schemes have not focused their activities on the smallholder producers who are increasingly dominating the dairy industry in the region. Breeding value estimation and selection for improved productivity would be difficult, therefore, without well defined breeding objectives and reliable performance recording system. With respect to distribution of selected breeding animals AI has been playing a significant role in Ethiopia. However, its activities have been unsatisfactory and limited to the Capital and some major cities due to a number of technical, financial, infrastructural and managerial constraints that prevail in the developing counties (Azage, 1995). On the other hand bull service for dairy breed improvement is being practiced as an option to a limited extent by some governmental and non-governmental institutions like the SDDP in the rural Ethiopia, however, the sustainability of this option is in question due to the uncertainty of the economic status of farmers to replace bulls (Bittner et al., 2000).

Furthermore, improvement of the already existing indigenous genotypes or their replacement with superior types depends on the knowledge of the attributes of these genotypes and the socio-economic factors that affect production in those environments (Trail, 1984). The conventional methods lack awareness on the traditional management systems operating within the existing constraints. Therefore, gathering of additional information pertaining the current breeding and cattle management practices from farmers and opinion leaders in a participatory process for the development of a national or regional breeding programs has become a prerequisite to formulate appropriate and acceptable breeding programs for the improvement of cattle productivity. In addition, reviewing the current role of modern breeding tools and technologies and level of application in the country is essential (Sendros and Tesfaye, 1997).

Natural mating as a means to propagate improved genotypes has to be tested against the risk of venereal diseases some of which are zoonotic. In general, venereal diseases affect fertility by altering the reproductive environment, so that there may be impaired sperm transport, sperm death or embryonic and fetal deaths. There are several sexually transmitted bacterial, protozoal., viral and mycoplasmal infections. Brucellosis is one of these diseases with a significant negative effect on fertility. The fact that this disease could be transmitted through natural service and AI makes it more important than other infectious causes of infertility.

A number of investigations done on Brucellosis in Ethiopia indicate that it is more prevalent in improved breeds of cattle, that are believed to be the best options to improve the dairy productivity in the country. The prevalence in improved breeds varies from 7.62% to 38.7 % while in locals it varies from 3% to 4.2 % (Abebe, 1989, Bayleyegn, 1989, Endrias, 1989, Muktar, 1993 and Tekelye et al, 1989). Tariku (1994) estimated that the annual economic loss due to Brucellosis, that arises from abortion, extended calving interval and increased culling rate, in Cheffa State Farm in Ethiopia, amounts to Birr 88, 941.96 (approximately 11,000 EUR).

chapter.head: Objectives
chapter.p: The objectives of this study are the following:
2.1. To understand the conditions of dairy production systems
2.1.1. Characterizing the farming systems
2.1.2. Identify factors affecting the estimated performances of dairy cattle
2.2. To understand the existing breeding practices by farmers
2.2.1. Identify the preferred performance traits by farmers
2.2.2. Identify sources of information to acquire dairy cows
2.2.3. Identify the preferred options to improve dairy productivity

and quantify farm incidences of abortion and prevalence of Brucellosis.

section.head: Status and prospect of the dairy industry

subsection.head: Status of the dairy industry
subsection.p: In the western world, the dairy industry is dominated by family farms. However, a strong trend towards larger farms has emerged in recent years that result in a drastic reduction in the number of farms. In Eastern Europe countries, that are in a process of transition, the large collective dairy farms have been privatized and often have been split up into smaller farms. The process of transition is, however, accompanied by great uncertainties due to the unclear and uncertain economic and political situation and also to the inappropriate dairy policy. In the developing countries, there are milk producers that practice traditional and non-traditional dairy productions. In areas that practice the non-traditional dairy production, the structure of dairying is more varied. Besides small farms there are also large scale specialized dairy farms. In the traditional milk producing regions, specially those of Africa, the structure of milk production is characterized by small farms with not more than three or four animals. Dairying is nearly always part of a mixed farming system. Livestock are fed principally on agricultural residues and are grazed on natural pastures of non-arable land. Cattle husbandry and milk production is largely supported by the by-products of agriculture (Schelhaas, 1999). The dairy cows produce food to the family, provide direct cash income, are capital assets, produce manure for use as fertilizers and fuel and may be source of power for transport and cultivation. The highlands of Sub-Saharan Africa are the most productive in terms of milk per ha in the traditional dairy production system, but production per head of cattle is lower than in the dry zone (70 Vs 58 kg); this is because the majority of cattle are found in the Ethiopian highlands, where male stock used for traction comprise a high fraction of the herd (de Leeuw et al, 1999).

subsection.head: Prospects of the dairy industry
subsection.p:
Delgado et al. (2001) forecasted that there will be globally an increment in demand for milk and milk products, in the next two decades, fueled by population growth, urbanization and income growth (de Leeuw et al., 1999). The strongest growth in demand for milk and milk products is anticipated to come from developing countries, where it is projected to grow at the rate of 3 percent annually (Griffin, 1999). Africa south of the Sahara is
expected to register 3.3 % increase in demand for milk and milk products in 2020 (Delgado et al., 2001). In addition, world production of milk is also forecasted to grow by an annual rate of slightly over one percent and the largest increment is expected in developing countries (Griffin, 1999). Delgado et al. (2001) projected the annual growth rate of milk production in developing countries between 1997-2020 to be 2.73% and a 4% annual growth in milk production was projected between 1993 and 2020 in Sub-Saharan Africa (Delgado et al., 1999).

In addition, internationalization and privatization are also among the forces that are acting towards change. A number of agreements have been signed that would represent a major breakthrough on the road towards a free world dairy market. These agreements have been aimed at a reduction of the level of domestic market protection and a lowering of export subsidies by the developed world and hence to an enlargement of the scope for imports (Schelhaas, 1999).

Nevertheless, a number of factors will continue to limit the development of the dairy industry in the Sub-Saharan Africa. Higher levels of production than those achieved in traditional tropical systems often require the improvement of the productivity of dairy breeds, improved feed base, adoption of new technologies and equipment to improve production efficiency and improving levels of inputs and infrastructure; both for milk sales and input acquisition (Egan, 1999 and De Boer, 1999). It could be difficult for many countries in the Sub-Saharan Africa to satisfactorily meet these requirements due to their poor financial and technical capabilities.

section.head: Dairy production systems in Ethiopia
section.p: Four major systems of dairy production can be distinguished in Ethiopia. These are: lowland pastoral dairy production systems, rural highland small-holder dairy production system, urban and peri-urban small scale dairy production system and large scale dairy production system.

subsection.head: Lowland pastoralist dairy farming
subsection.p:
About 30% of the livestock population in Ethiopia are found in the pastoral areas. These areas comprise 50% of the total land area of the country and have altitudes below 1500m.a.s.l. Pastoralism is the major dairy production system in the lowland. Livestock
doesn't provide inputs for crop production but are the very backbone of their owners providing all of the consumable and saleable out puts and regarded as insurance against adversity. Milk production is dependent on season due to the rainfall pattern that influences feed availability (Ketema and Tsehay, 1995).

subsection.head: Rural highland small-holder dairy farming
subsection.p: There are two types of systems in the highland. The traditional system that is based on indigenous breeds and the market oriented system that is based on crossbred dairy cattle. The average lactation yield for indigenous cows is 524 liters for 239 days and the average age at first calving is 53 months and the average calving interval is 25 months. Tesfaye (1995) reported that the average milk yield and lactation length for crossbred dairy cows ranges from 518.8-1448 kg and 110-300 days, respectively, depending on the breed type. The milk produced is mainly consumed by the household in the traditional system while most of the milk is sold to generate income in the market oriented system.

subsection.head: Urban and peri-urban small scale dairy farming
subsection.p: This system is developed in and around major cities and towns located mainly in the highlands of Ethiopia. The main feed resources are agro-industrial byproducts and purchased roughage. The system comprises small and medium sized dairy farms that own crossbreed dairy cows. Farmers use all or part of their land for forage production. The primary objective of milk production is generating additional cash income to the household (Ketema and Tsehay, (1995) and Azage et al., (2000)).

subsection.head: Large scale dairy farming
subsection.p: This system is a specialized market oriented dairy operation practiced by the state sector and very few private commercial farms. Most of these farms are located in and around Addis Ababa and basically keep exotic dairy stock (Ketema and Tsehay, (1995) and Azage et al., (2000)).

section.head: The role of the dairy sector in the Ethiopian economy
section.p:
At household level dairying is important in one way or another in all the farming systems of Ethiopia. In pastoralist farming system and the crop farming areas milk is the most important source of protein (Tilahun, 1995). In the mixed farming systems milk is also
used mainly as food to the household and to a lesser extent as a source of income (FAO,1999). In the urban and peri-urban areas dairy production is practiced mainly as a source of income.

At macro-level, there is scarcity of information that estimate the share of the dairy sector in the GDP. However, the report of Azage and Alemu (1997) indicted that 800, 000 metric tones of milk are produced every year. The very low per capita consumption of milk (20 kg per annum) is lower than the average for Sub-Saharan Africa, and this indicates that the actual level of dairy productivity is extremely low.

section.head: The prospects of dairy farming in Ethiopia
section.p: An increase in total human population and accelerated rate of urbanization characterize the Ethiopian society in the coming 25 years. The urban community with high purchasing power represent the main milk market. There will be, therefore, an increase in demand for milk and milk products in the future in urban areas and, hence, large commercial and market oriented small-holder peri-urban dairy production systems have tremendous potential for development.

section.head: Constraints of Dairy Production in Ethiopia

subsection.head: Increasing human population and the composition of livestock population
subsection.p: The human population in Ethiopia, currently estimated at 60 million is growing by about 3.5% per annum with an estimated population of about 139 million by the year 2020 (Azage and Alemu, 1997). This high population growth will force people to cultivate more land at the cost of grazing land and requires more traction power and as a result the herd in particular and the livestock population at large will be composed more of traction animals that create pressure on the grazing land (Ketema and Tsehay, 1995).

subsection.head: Policy and socioeconomic issues
subsection.p:
Land ownership and land rights : the 1975 land reform legislation abolished all forms of private ownership of land and put land under state control (Desalegn, 1984) and land ownership remains still in the hands of the state (Girma and Zegeye, 1996 and USDC, 1999). The issue of land ownership with respect to dairy production is particularly important in the urban and peri-urban areas. The land policy doesn't make individuals, who
already have land, free and secure to invest more on the land and there is also scarcity and difficulty in acquiring new land. Land for investment purposes could be obtained by lease, with prices set by periodic auctions, which is beyond the capability of most of the small scale and medium scale dairy farmers.

Farmers' participation : farmers have in general limited opportunity and authority to participate in decision making processes for what is economically, socially and culturally good for them. Most obviously, government intervention is based on a top-down development approach which has lead to the imposition of ideas (Tesfaye, 1990).

Dairy policy : three general periods of changing dairy policy can be identified in Ethiopia. The first era under the imperial regime favored the large indigenous commercial farmers in peri-urban areas which were assisted by subsidized milk collection, assured land tenure and free markets for feed and other issues. However, the small-holder dairy producers had no means to get improved dairy cows and thus their development was suppressed. The period under the socialist regime was characterized by nominal but not actual support for small-holders. The actual support was for unprofitable large scale state farm productions. The policies during this time increased the uncertainties of land tenure, feed supply restrictions and reduced formal producer prices. In the present period, the government starts to liberalize dairy policies but the changes are gradual. Private producers can participate at a greater degree and there are no feed supply restrictions (Staal and Shapiro, 1996).

Dairy import policy : dairy imports have implications on food availability, overall imports and the development of domestic milk production. Import policies regarding dairy products in most African countries are usually targeted at generating revenue for the national budget, to provide consumers with dairy products at reasonable prices, to stimulate domestic dairy developments and move towards self-sufficiency and to control the balance of foreign exchange. The problem is that governments pursue several objectives simultaneously that may be contradictory and unbalanced (von Massow, 1989). In Ethiopia, importation of dairy products to partially fulfill local demand of the formal market dominated the dairy sector in the last two decades. According to the 1994 report of DDE, imported dairy products have a substantial market share in Addis Ababa (Belachew, 1997) and have impact on the price of milk from local producers.

Marketing system and price policy : Staal et al. (1998) indicated that most milk and dairy marketing (88%) occurs through the informal sector and Belachew (1997) had reported the same. The informal marketing system involves direct delivery of fresh milk by producers to consumers in the immediate neighborhood and sales to itinerate traders or individuals in nearby towns. The informal market is scarce especially for the smallholder farmers during the fasting season of the Ethiopian Orthodox Christians when people do not eat animal products (Rüther et al., 1998). The formal milk marketing system were dominated by Dairy Development Enterprise (DDE), which functions as milk producer, collector and processor. However, following the liberalization of the dairy policy, with which the government intervention in the marketing and pricing of livestock products is minimized, private institutions also have started taking part in milk collection and processing business.

Credit facilities and incentives : credit is a very important tool in dairy development by providing farmers with a capacity to invest in order to increase productivity of the dairy operations. Available credits from the Agricultural and Industrial Development Bank in Ethiopia are targeted to the crop sector mainly for purchases of oxen, fertilizers and improved seed. According to the 1990-94 Rural Credit Performance Reports of AIDB, the livestock sectors share was only 3% of the total credit services given to the rural community (Bekele, 1995). In Ethiopia, incentives given to dairy producers to enhance their development is not broad based and is limited to a very small proportion of the total number of dairy farmers.

Environmental issues : environmental issues associated with the pastoral and highland small-holder dairy production systems are overgrazing and land degradation that are the results of continuous utilization of crop lands and communal grazing lands without rehabilitation and conservation works. Hygienic and sanitary hazard and pollution of soil, water and air due to a large volume of waste and close human-animal interaction are environmental risks associated with the urban, peri-urban and the intensive commercial dairy production systems (FAO, 1999).

Quality control and public health issues : there are no official rules and regulations to control the quality of milk produced and distributed to consumers. At the DDE milk quality control and pasteurization is practiced routinely for milk entering the processing plant, which is a very small proportion of the total amount of milk produced in the country
(13%) (Rüther et al., 1998). Yilkal (1998) reported that the highest proportion of milk (71%) is distributed to consumers informally as raw milk without passing through any type of quality and safety tests. However, this problem is expected to reduce with currently flourishing private business institutions doing pasteurization and processing of milk.

Infrastructure : partial or complete lack of properly constructed all weather roads in the country affects rural dairy farming in that farmers are not able to deliver dairy products to the open market and buy dairy inputs easily. Furthermore, most of the animal feeds are byproducts of human food production plants with an unreliable availability. The small number of state owned and private animal feed production plants do not fulfill the demand of the growing dairy farming sector. The veterinary service coverage in Ethiopia is 77034 VLU (Veterinary Livestock Unit) per veterinarian and 37904 VLU per assistant veterinarian (Daborn et al, 1998 and ILCA, 1993). The VLU per veterinarian is below the recommended value where as the VLU per assistant veterinarians, that work very close to or within the rural community, is more than three times the recommended value. Even if the VLU value per veterinarian is below the recommended, a recent study in some part of Ethiopia indicated that more than 43% of them are stationed in the regional capitals and the roads to the rural area are poorly developed (Catley, 1999).

subsection.head: Institutional constraints
subsection.p: Research and information exchange systems : considering the importance of a central institution to guide and coordinate agricultural researches and an organized information system to publicize results of research works, new technologies and policy (Goshu, 1995), EARO (Ethiopian Agricultural Research Organization) has been established in 1997.

Lack of education, extension and consultation : there is shortage of qualified personnel, poor education and management expertise of farmers, misunderstanding of production systems, lack of extension works to transfer new technologies and knowledge gained through researches to farmers, ignorance of the experience and knowledge of local farmers and absence of forums for consultations and discussions with farmers (Sendros and Tesfaye, 1997).

subsection.head: Technical constraints
subsection.p: Health : a number of parasitic, bacterial, fungal and viral diseases and nutritional deficiencies which are prevalent in the country affect the productivity and reproductive efficiency of dairy cattle and make individuals insecure to be involved in and invest on dairy production specially using cows with exotic blood. Among these diseases, venereal diseases have a direct effect while and nutritional deficiencies and other infectious diseases play an indirect role in hampering the reproductive efficiency of dairy cows. Moreover, extensive areas in the humid zone are Tse-tse infested and hence are unfavorable for livestock production (Teferra, 1993).

Feed resource availability : natural grazing is the most important source of feed in both the highland small-holder and pastoral dairy farming. It is estimated that over 90% of the total animal feed is obtained from unimproved and communal pasture, rangeland and fallow. In the highlands grazing resources have deteriorated as a result of human population pressure and the intensity of cultivation while in the lowlands livestock are restricted to areas close to permanent water sources during the dry season. Crop residues and byproducts of agricultural processing account for the remaining 7 and 3 percent, respectively (Tilahun, 1995). The urban and peri-urban dairy production systems depend more on industrial byproduct feeds whose availability is not dependable since the production level is far below the demand.

Animal genetic resources : according to Tsehay (1997), about 99% of the cattle population in Ethiopia are indigenous that are adapted to feed and water shortages, disease challenges and harsh climates. The productivity of indigenous livestock is, however, believed to be poor even if no practical recording scheme has been used to judge their merit. Crossbreeding has been practiced with encouraging results, however, a strictly controlled breeding program has not been practiced (Tesfaye, 1990) and there has been no dairy herd recording scheme (Alemu et al., 1993).

section.head: Past dairy research activities
section.p:
Dairy research has been carried out in Ethiopia as part of agricultural research activities and dates back to the late 1940's and early 1950's with the establishment of some of the agricultural teaching institutions. Since 1966 IAR (the Institute of Agricultural Researches)
has become the leading agricultural research institute in the country. In addition, the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA), the National Veterinary Institute (NVI), the National Tse-tse and Trypanosomiasis Investigation Center (NTTIC), Awassa College of Agriculture, the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine (FVM) at Debre Zeit and the Institute of Development Studies are directly or indirectly involved in livestock research (Goshu, 1995).

In 1997, the Ethiopian Agricultural Research Organization (EARO) has been established with the proclamation number of 79/1997 of the Federal Negarit Gazetta of the Federal Government of Ethiopia. EARO is the highest autonomous government body and the largest specialized agency to co-ordinate agricultural research activities in the country. EARO is primarily responsible for generating, improving and adapting technologies, coordinating, encouraging and assisting research activities and popularize agricultural research results (Frehiwot, 1997).

section.head: Dairy cattle breeding methods
section.p: The present livestock breeds in the world are the results of both natural selection and human intervention. Natural selection operates to provide reproductive ability and continuity of the fittest while human intervention is to change one or more traits of animals that the owner thinks desirable under his environment. The genetic variations available both within breeds and between breeds, has been used to accommodate interests and farmers wishes to make livestock more efficient in using available resources to produce human food and other agricultural products (Sendros and Tesfaye, 1997 and Rendel, 1991). The following are the commonly used dairy cattle breeding methods:
Selection within breeds: pure breeding

The goal is to build additive genetic gains into the population by identifying individual superior genotypes and preferentially multiplying them in the next generation (Payne and Hodges, 1997). This is the method of greatest use with cattle in the West and there are also reports of successful implementation of local breed improvements through selection in the tropics like the case of Sahiwal breed in India (Trail and Gregory, 1988). Since traits like milk yield and fertility are poorly inherited selection should include some form of progeny test and pedigree information (Payne and Wilson, 1999). However, more elaborate schemes for sire-progeny testing requiring a large active breeding population with milk recording and AI are not compatible with the level of communication, infrastructure and
production intensity in most warm climate dairy systems and hence simpler schemes have to be developed for evaluating local genetic resource (Peters, 1991).
Crossbreeding: mating parents of two or more different breeds together

The basic objectives of crossbreeding of high performing cattle breeds with tropical breeds is to produce crossbreds with an expected additive genetic merit being the mean of both parental breeds. The non-additive effect which is observed as heterosis or hybrid vigor is the amount by which merit in crossbreds deviate from the additive component (Kinghorn, 2000) and is fully exploited only when non-related breeds are crossed. Payne and Hodges (1997) indicated that hybrid vigor becomes greater when the differences in the parental genetic make-up is high and Barlow (1981) suggested the possibility of greater hybrid vigor in more stressful environments. The use of temperate dairy breeds for crossbreeding with indigenous breeds has been widely accepted and aims at combining the superior performance of specialized dairy breeds with the superior adaptability of the local stock (Peters, 1991). According to Cunningham (1991) the crosses between the temperate dairy cattle breeds and local cattle in the tropics combined the milk producing ability of the temperate breeds with the climatic adaptability of the tropical breeds (Cunningham, 1991). However, the delicate balance between genetic performance ability and adaptability is determined by the degree of exotic inheritance (Peters, 1991). Many reports on the performance of crossbred cattle indicated that crossbreeding results in performance improvement only until 50% inheritance of Bos taurus genes. Cunningham and Syrstad (1988) analyzed 46 data sets from different tropical countries and concluded that there was a nearly linear improvement of milk yield, age at first calving and calving interval up to 50% Bos taurus inheritance and F 2 was inferior to F 1 in all the traits studied. Syrstad (1985) and Vaccaro (1990) have also concluded that further upgrading more than 50% Bos taurus inheritance has negative effects on age at first calving, calving interval, survivability and herd life. Furthermore, Madalena (1993) reported that performance declined in back crosses as the Holstein-Friesian gene fraction departed higher or lower than 50%. Cunningham (1991) indicated that the possible explanation for the low productivity of F 2 is the idea that blocks of genes giving favorable epistatic effects in the parental breeds and the F 1 may be broken up in the F 2 and subsequent generations.

section.head: Dairy cattle breed improvement strategy
section.p: To achieve a meaningful development in livestock productivity through genetic improvement, sustainable and effective animal genetic improvement programs need to be planned, implemented and maintained. The following are some important considerations in designing such program.

subsection.head: Breeding goal definition
subsection.p: It is the first step to be made in designing genetic improvement strategies. The breeding goal identifies those traits that farmers would like to improve. To be able to identify the traits, the existing and future development objective of the agricultural production in the country is to be defined and the livestock production system to be characterized. The current livestock population structure should be described and opportunities, to better utilize it and hence, maximize the realization of genetic gain, should be sought for and some appropriate changes should be made (Hammond and Galal, 2000). Payne and Hodges (1997) stated that breeding goals should match the expectations and values of the community. Furthermore, each trait in the breeding goal is given a 'goal value', indicating the contribution of the improvement of the trait to the realization of the development objectives. Since the relative rate of improvement will be faster for traits which have higher heritabilities, emphases should be given to traits with acceptable heritability. As a general guideline, traits with heritabilities less than 10% are considered lowly heritable and one can not realistically expect to make much genetic progress (Funk, 1992 ).

subsection.head: Breeding value prediction
subsection.p:
Identification of those cattle with the highest breeding value for traits in breeding goal, is the second step that require performance and pedigree recording system. Estimation of breeding value needs to be based on trait measurement, either on the animal or on animals genetically related to the individual (van der Werf, 1999). Estimation of breeding value based on an animal's phenotype alone can be quiet accurate for high heritable traits like milk quality traits. A progeny test is usually the most accurate assessment of breeding value based on the performance of the offspring of the animal and it requires sufficient number of progeny to be tested (Payne and Wilson, 1999 and van der Werf, 1999). Payne and Wilson (1999) stated that progeny test is usually applied for bulls and is particularly
valuable method where the heritability of the trait is low like milk yield and where the increase in generation interval, implicit in the methodology, is not too pronounced. Syrstad (1998) indicated that the rate of gain from progeny testing programs suffers from the fact that it takes so long for the bulls daughter to be recorded. Furthermore, Peters (1991) stated that sire-progeny testing requiring a large active breeding population with milk recording and AI are not compatible with the existing conditions in tropical dairy systems. Another alternative basis for breeding value estimation is pedigree information that takes into account the performance of ancestors. This method can be of value only if the pedigree information is complete (Payne and Wilson, 1999). Syrstad (1998) reported that selection of bulls based on pedigree information only gave the fastest genetic improvement. He further elaborated that many practical factors favor breeding schemes with lower generation intervals like pedigree selection over progeny testing.

subsection.head: Organization of a breeding strategy
subsection.p:
It
is the third step and involves the designing of a well organized breeding strategy for the use of cattle with predicted breeding value and the dissemination of superior genes through the population (Groen, 2000). At this step is decided which animals to use as parents and in what combination (Kinghorn, 1999).

Simple field performance testing and an open nucleus breeding schemes operated through breeders associations or group breeding schemes has been indicated by Peters (1991) as an option to improve the productivity of indigenous breeds while Payne and Hodges (1997) recommended the same breeding scheme with recording and selection to take place in a local cattle station.

For crossbreeding, the establishment of an open nucleus breeding herd of indigenous cows by genetic screening of the local cow population and crossbreeding them with temperate sires to produce F 1 bulls either to distribute the bulls to local cattle owners for natural service in the field population or to use their semen for AI in areas where AI is available and working successfully has been proposed by Payne and Hodges (1997). Another option proposed by Madalena (1993) advocates the continuous production of and supply of replacement F 1 heifers, that are produced by dairy farmers specializing in proving replacement heifers, to dairy farmers. In addition, Payne and Hodges (1997) indicated that a breeding strategy in the tropics should also consider the alternative uses of another
breeds indigenous to the tropics and purebred selection within the local indigenous cattle in cases where the use of temperate gene is not appropriate. Payne and Hodges (1997) and Horst (1998) further stressed the importance of introducing a package approach in which any genetic improvement program is accompanied by improved management, animal health, marketing options for the products and extension support with trained local people.

With respect to dissemination of selected genes it is important to determine simple and efficient methods of gene transfer in the existing socio-economic conditions and production system (Kinghorn, 1999 and Payne and Hodges, 1997). Payne and Hodges (1997) stressed that in the vast majority of settings in the tropics with small scale owners, AI has failed and should not be included as part of a cattle breeding strategy and they recommended the use of natural mating using breeding sires. However, in areas where AI could be properly organized, it is advantageous to use AI since it allows the maximum exploitation of the best sires and a reduction in the total number of sires that have to be maintained (Payne and Wilson, 1999).

section.head: Dairy cattle breed improvement activities in Ethiopia
section.p:
Dairy cattle breed improvement program, in Ethiopia, was launched during the occupation of Ethiopia by Italy with importation of exotic dairy cattle. Later on, the First Livestock Development Project (1958-63) created the Dairy Development Agency (DDA) that was concerned mainly with the development of commercial dairy farms in Addis Ababa (Fekadu, 1990). Crossbreeding has been started by the Institute of Agricultural Research, through the establishment of an on-station Dairy Cattle Crossbreeding Program, using Friesian, Jersey and Simmental sires that were crossed with the local Horro, Boran and Barka dams with the aim of testing the productivity of crossbred dairy cows with different levels of exotic blood (EARO 1, 2001). The Chilalo Agricultural Development Project (CADU), an integrated project established jointly by the Ethiopian and Swedish Governments, in Arsi region initiated intensive small scale dairy development in Ethiopia in 1967/68 (Kiwuwa et al, 1983). This was followed by the Wolayta Agricultural Development Project (WADU) that was established in 1971 and funded by the World Bank, basically applied the CADU program (Haile Mariam, 1994). The livestock breed improvement program under MOA, that was an integral part of the National Livestock Development Projects, has also contributed to the establishment of dairy cattle
improvement ranches in different parts of the country. The focus of the program was on increasing the milk productivity of local breeds through crossbreeding and distribution of F 1 heifers to farmers (EARO 1 , 2001). In 1987 a FINNIDA funded project of the MOA started to improve dairy cattle productivity at the highlands of Ethiopia through the establishment of the Selale Peasant Dairy Development Pilot Project. SPDDPP introduced crossbred dairy cattle and improved management skills with the objective to increase the living standard of small-holder farmers. Since 1995, the Small-holder Dairy Development Project, SDDP, that can be considered as the continuation of the pilot project with the same objectives but broader spectrum of activities operated in the different parts of the country. The project had been distributing crossbred dairy cows and pure-bred Friesian and Jersey breeding bulls and introduced improved methods of fodder production in the project areas (MOA/SDDP, 1996). According to the 1999 SDDP report of the Oromia Regional Government, the project had distributed 167 in calf heifers and 58 breeding bulls to contact farmers at Selale area. The number of crossbred dairy cows at Selale area increased to 342 and in addition, 4859 cows were mated with improved bulls from which 1093 calves had been born.

However, according to EARO1 (2001), the genetic improvement activities for dairy production in Ethiopia were constrained by a number of factors. Climatic stress in the form of erratic and inadequate rainfall; low fodder yield potential and high price for concentrate and susceptibility to a wide variety of serious diseases detrimentally affect the productivity of genetically improved dairy cattle specially the upgraded ones. Poor education and management expertise of farmers have also been hindrances in the implementation and maintenance of genetic improvement programs.

section.head: Dairy cattle breeding policy in Ethiopia
section.p: Despite the number of attempts in the past years to improve the genetic potential of the local dairy cows through crossbreeding, there has been no concrete and binding breeding policy with regard to the choice of the exotic breed types to be crossed with the indigenous animals and the optimal exotic blood level of the crosses to be attained in different production systems.

Even if it has not been implemented, there was a policy proposal, prepared by the Ministry of Agriculture in 1985 for Government decision to conduct an inventory of the livestock
situation in the country and to set priorities regarding the types of livestock productions that are suitable for the different agro-ecological zones in the country. The proposal recommended to practice pure-breeding of Friesian cattle in urban dairy systems and large scale government farms and the selection of superior sires for AI. The proposal also suggested to produce and maintain Friesian and Jersey crossbreds (50%-75%) with indigenous cows and their distribution to small-holder farmers (Sjoberg, 1985). The choice of the Friesian and Jersey breeds was suggested to be linked with feed availability and the potential market for liquid milk. The policy recommends Jersey crosses for areas where milk had to be processed before reaching market and where the feed availability is less promising (Tesfaye, 1990). In addition, the proposal gave also significant consideration to the indigenous breeds and recommended their development for crossbreeding program and preservation. Furthermore, the policy proposal indicated that the National AI Scheme should adopt a strong and functional organization that can win the farmers confidence and also the necessity of a well organized national dairy recording scheme that works in close cooperation with the National AI Scheme.

Recently, a draft proposal for a new livestock breeding policy has been prepared by the Ethiopian Agricultural Research Organization (EARO) with the general objective of attaining sustainable increase in cattle productivity and socio-economic development (EARO1, 2001). Achievement of self-sufficiency in milk and milk products in both quality and quantity is one of the specific objectives of the draft policy. It has been indicated in the policy that a cattle breeding program in Ethiopia shall take into account the different agro-ecological zones and shall be implemented in accordance with socio-economic conditions prevailing in the areas.

The policy promotes the developed use of indigenous and exotic animal breeds, having superior production traits, that are relatively more tolerant to diseases, environmental stress and sub-optimal nutritional conditions. It also emphasizes the need for conservation of indigenous genetic resources. According to the policy, the national cattle breeding program shall have the following three components:

1. Cattle breed zoning is done based on the current distribution of breeds, objectives of livestock keeping, the physical environment, socio-economic conditions, prevailing farming system and availability of infrastructure (EARO 2, 2001). Cattle breeds are thus
located to zones that suit their biology so that productivity is optimized. The policy also recommends the preparation of appropriate laws and regulations to restrict some breeds to some zones for specific purposes.

2. The draft policy recommends four alternatives of breeds to be used: indigenous, exotic, crossbred and synthetic. It is proposed that the indigenous cattle shall be left to prosper to preserve the indigenous gene pool and efforts should be made to improve their utilization within their system environment. The use of acclimatized exotic breeds that are selected and bred under local conditions has also been suggested. Crossbred cattle whose exotic blood level ranging within 50-62.5% shall be used to avoid the adaptation problem. The policy encourages governmental and non-governmental institutions to develop synthesized breeds that are targeted for certain production environments that require multipurpose breeds (EARO 2, 2001).

3. As to the breeding methods, pure-breeding is recommended to improve desirable traits. An open nucleus breeding program has been indicated in the draft policy to be appropriate for subsistence production systems in Ethiopia. Pure-breeding and multiplication of exotic breeds using more promising and improved tropical breeds is recommended for all high potential intensive dairy areas. Crossbreeding of indigenous breeds with exotic breeds, integrated with performance recording and selection program within the local cattle, is the second option mentioned in the draft policy. It is stressed that potential breeds for cross breeding should be identified and tagged to facilitate follow-ups and the crossbreeding program shall be monitored and evaluated regularly. The third option is rotational crossbreeding: using exotic and local breeds in alternate generations to take advantage of changing market demands (EARO 2, 2001).

Considering all the above three components of the breed improvement program for Ethiopia, the draft policy proposes, therefore, intensive dairying for high rainfall, tse-tse free, peri-urban, highly populated and accessible areas. According to the draft policy semi-intensive dairying is most suited for medium rainfall, medium altitude, tse-tse free, medium population density, peri-urban and accessible areas. Pure temperate dairy breeds such as Friesian and Jersey and their high grade crosses shall be promoted as being the best for both the intensive and semi-intensive dairying. Dairy ranching with crosses of indigenous and temperate dairy breeds up to F 1 and tropical dairy breeds like Sahiwal, Red
Sindhi and Kenana, is most suited for low rainfall, rural, tse-tse free and lowland areas. Extensive multi-purpose production systems are most suited for low rainfall, medium to low altitude, rural areas, low population density areas and accessible areas. The use of improved indigenous breeds as a development and genetic resource conservation strategy shall be adopted. In addition, synthetic breeds shall be developed for milk, meat and draft purposes and disease resistance (EARO 2, 2001).

Furthermore, the draft policy suggests sanctions to be imposed on the importation of genetic materials, including live animal, semen, ova and embryo, that are not verified to be free of any disease and genetic defects by a designated authority. The policy also restricts the importation and use of breeds other than those included in the list of suitable breeds for widespread use, that is prepared and updated regularly by the designated authority. Other breeds not appearing on the list shall only be allowed into the country for restricted use on designated locations like experimental stations and specialized production units (EARO 2, 2001).

section.head: Review of the organization and efficiency of bull mating and AI schemes

subsection.head: Natural mating
subsection.p: The use of bulls for natural service remains widespread even in areas where artificial insemination has proven to be very efficient. Many farmers believe that pregnancy rates are higher when a bull is used. The use of natural service may be indicated when personnel are inefficient to perform the tasks associated with heat detection and the techniques of AI, when long term genetic gain is of minor importance and when local conditions do not provide the infrastructure necessary for successful AI (Wattiaux, 1998).
Selecting for breeding soundness of bulls

In undertaking natural mating, the bull must be morphologically and functionally sound. Testicles should have a distinct neck and should not be fibrotic or flaccid in consistency. This is essential because testicles must be a reasonable distance away from the internal body temperature. A scrotal circumference of 30cm and 34 cm is recommended for 15 months old and 24 months old Friesian bulls respectively (Jensen, 1997). Azage et al. (1997) indicated that there is a direct relationship between scrotal circumference and semen production. Bulls should also have good body condition and have morphologically
sound feet and legs and healthy eyes to perform the service properly. A breeding bull is required also to have a good libido or serving capacity. Mickelson (1990) reported that the serving capacity of a bull is positively correlated with the proportion of heat detected cows. Differences in pregnancy rates were also associated with high, medium and low serving capacities of bulls (Chenoweth, 2000). If conditions allow, it is also essential to perform a rectal examination for abnormalities of accessory sex organs and to do semen evaluation tests. Furthermore, farmers must be careful to select preferably a crossbred between the local and improved breeds for cows that are small and local type, which has a greater probability of siring small calves which will not cause problems at calving time (Lee et al., 1998).
Managing a breeding bull

Appropriate attention should be given to factors affecting fertility of bulls that include unbalanced nutrition (under feeding and over feeding) and diseases. Adequate nutrition is vital, since it hastens puberty and body development. It is also important to keep in mind that overfeeding can lead to reduced libido (Sprott et al., 1998). Bulls should also be tested for venereal diseases like Brucellosis, Trichomonosis and Vibriosis that affect fertility and culled if they react positively. In addition, prevention measures like vaccination and deworming should be undertaken against other diseases that influence fertility indirectly (Sprott et al., 1997).

It is important to undertake a regular fertility test for bulls to verify their external physical soundness, reproductive health (congenital and inflammatory problems), scrotal circumference and semen quality. Jensen (1997) indicated that up to 20% of all bulls have less than optimum fertility. To avoid undesired mating, farmers should castrate all other bulls they have and prevent outside bulls from coming into the herd (Lee et al., 1998).

Another factor to be considered is the temperament of breeding bulls which is genetically determined and is also affected by management. Viciousness makes bulls unmanageable and it is often the result of confinement and ill treatment. Proper daily handling, firm training and exercise make most bulls fairly tractable and easily controlled (Chenoweth, 2000).

Bulls are culled for reasons such as low performing offspring, morphological deformities, eye problems, and age related problems of low quality semen and inadequate serving capacities (Sprott et al, 1997).
Organization of natural mating

Organization of natural mating includes the required number of bulls, service interval, service length and replacement rate, heat detection skills, times of service, and mating record keeping. Barett and Larkin (1974) recommended 30-40 cows per bull under traditional method in which bulls run with the cows in one herd. Sambraus (1978) reported that, in temperate climates dual purpose bull serve on average 12 times a day over a period of several weeks. For hand mating system in which a bull is kept separated from the cows and mating is done at owner's discretion, a bull-cow ration of 1: 50-60 is recommended by Barrett and Larkin (1974). Zumbach and Peters (2000) suggested based on the recommendations of Barrett and Larkin (1974) a mating period of eight weeks with which eight cows can be served per week.

Breeding bulls should be replaced to avoid inbreeding. Previous works recommend not to use a bull for more than two to four years in a herd without replacement or switching with bulls from other sites (Lee et al, 1998 and IIRR, 2000).

The hand mating system requires accurate heat detection skills and proper timing of services by the farmers. In a controlled breeding experiment in Sri Lanka, most farmers were unaware that their animals were displaying estrous cycles (Abeyratne et al. (1983). Esslemont et al (1985) recommended that it is useful to watch for heat three or four times a day, leaving not more than 8 hours between visits in order to improve heat detection rates up to 80%. Cows in heat must be served at the right time. Robert (1971) recommended that cows seen in estrus in the morning should be served that same day while those showing estrus later in the day should be served the next morning.
Efficiency of natural mating

Naidoo et al. (1981) reported in Mauritius that natural mating was more effective than AI with 91% of calving intervals being less than 14 months compared with only 49 % from AI. The work of Hailmariam et al. (1994) also indicated that the calving interval of Boran cows served by Boran bulls were shorter compared to those cows served by AI.

subsection.head: Reproductive technologies
subsection.p: There are a number of reproductive technologies being applied to transfer desirable genetic materials. These include Artificial Insemination (AI), Embryo Transfer (ET), Ovum Pick-up (OPU), In-Vitro Maturation and Fertilization (IVM/IVF) and Cloning (FAO, 2000). Of these only AI is the most commonly used technique in developing countries.

block.head: Artificial insemination
block.p: AI is an essential technique in breeding programs with progeny testing. According to Wittiaux (1998), AI provides the opportunity to choose sires that are proven to transmit desirable traits to the next generation and minimizes the risk of spreading sexually transmitted diseases and genetic defects. So far artificial insemination using frozen semen has played an important role in increasing genetic progress by upgrading the reproductive rate of the male. It increases the selection intensity since less bulls are needed and this is the basis for selection progress. Zumbach and Peters (2000) estimated that 1820 cows can be inseminated by a bull using deep frozen semen.

Despite the wide application and success of AI throughout the developed world, the success rate in African and other developing countries is still low owing to a number of technical, system related, financial and managerial problems (Azage et al, 1995). Among the technical constraints are poor heat detection skills, communication and transport problems that hamper timely insemination, poor semen collection and storage technology and handling procedures that affect semen quality, and inefficiency of AI technicians. Other system related problems include small herds, disperse locations, limited production intensity and affordable cost. Due to the poor financial capabilities of the countries means of communication and infrastructure are insufficient. It would also be difficult for the countries to bear costs for the production of liquid nitrogen and purchase of necessary equipments. The financial problem is further aggravated by the poor management of AI operations (FAO 2000).

According to the report of Chupin and Schuh (1992), AI coverage, semen production per year and AI applications per inseminator in Africa remains low. The same report indicated that the average AI applications per year per country in Africa is 30637 which is far below the values for Asian, Latin America and Near East countries (Table 3.1).

In addition, the pregnancy rate in AI scheme does not exceed 45% in Africa and the conception rate to first service was 48% in zebu cows kept at the Ministry of Agriculture Ranch in Ethiopia (Mukasa-Mugerwa et al. 1991a).

block.head: Embryo transfer
block.p: Embryo transfer in conjunction with multiple ovulation and estrus synchronization is a more advanced reproductive technology. The main advantage of ET is a higher selection among the females and more accurate breeding value estimation. Siedel (1989) estimated that embryo transfer could enhance the rate of genetic gain in the dairy industry from the female side by 3 to 4 fold. Its application is limited to developed countries because it is costly and requires highly developed technical skills. The application of ET in Africa has been, therefore, limited to research and development institutions. The technique have been applied in Africa at ILRAD to improve and multiply the N'Dama breed, which is indigenous in west Africa and is resistant to Trypanasomosis. ILCA also initiated an embryo transfer program at the Debre Zeit Research Station primarily on zebu cattle with the objectives of producing animals for research purposes and as a supportive tool for other research projects (Azage et al, 1995).

block.head: Reproductive technology in Ethiopia
block.p:
The most commonly and widely used reproductive technology in Ethiopia for over three decades is AI. According to the information released from the Artificial Insemination Center in 1995, AI was introduced to Ethiopia in the early 1930's and then interrupted by the II world war (NAIC, 1995). The activity was resumed in Addis Ababa and the
surrounding by the then Dairy Development Agency (DDA) that had been operating between 1958-1963. Since 1967 the AI was effectively and widely applied by the former Chilalo Agricultural Development Unit (CADU) in the present Arsi zone of Oromia. In addition, other institutions like the former Wolayta Agricultural Development Unit (WADU), Alemaya College of Agriculture, Institute of Agricultural Research (IAR) and the International Livestock Center for Africa (ILCA) had also been using AI in various areas of the country.

The National Artificial Insemination Center (NAIC) was established in 1981, under the Animal and Fisheries Resources Development Main Department (AFRDMD) of the Ministry of Agriculture with the mandate of organizing and coordinating AI activities as well as directing the breeding program at a national level (Azage et al., 1995)

The information released from the AI center in 1995 indicates that the Center has been operating with 58 staff members of which 30 are technical and 28 are supportive staff. In 1995, the AI service operated with 86 technicians in 86 sites of 7 regions of the country. The center is involved in semen and liquid nitrogen production, provision of regular group and individual training on AI to technicians and farmers, and dairy recording system.

The AI field service is currently carried out by AI technicians that are trained by the Center and assigned at the agricultural offices of the different regions of the country. The AI field service operates using three strategies. The first and widely used system is a daily round with which inseminators using motor bikes visit farms, villages and crush sites along side the main road. In this system, one AI technician covers an average of 50-60 km per day. The second system is called Static point with which AI technicians are stationed on farms where a large number of animals are kept. This is mainly practiced in large dairy farms, cattle collection centers (cows and heifers collected for insemination purposes for an average period of 3 months), and in cattle improvement and multiplication ranches. The third system operates on telephone call basis and this service is rendered in urban areas where telephone services are available.

Available data on annual semen production and distribution over the last ten years show no consistent trend. Figure 3.1 shows the number of straws produced and distributed in the years between 1984-1994.

block.p: The Center produced and distributed also about 100, 000 l of liquid nitrogen between 1984 and 1993 . Although it is not consistent, the production of liquid nitrogen shows an increasing trend through the years 1984-1994 (Figure 3.2).

The training and extension services of the Center include organization of seminars and workshops at different levels, dissemination of relevant information on AI to the public
through mass-media, and regular and in-service training courses for AI technicians. The Center has trained 259 technicians from 1984 to 2000.

Although the information collected is not complete and inconsistent, the center has a dairy recording system to evaluate the performances of AI bulls, to give technical and managerial advice to dairy farmers, to provide reliable and up-to date information on identifying bull dams to select breeding bulls of high pedigree records and to perform progeny testing of selected bulls.

Little information is available on the effectiveness of AI under field condition except for some research related results obtained by ILRI on the performance of AI at the Gobe Ranch in Ethiopia and reports compiled by the National AI Center based on field reports. The only information available from the National AI Center (1995) indicates that a total of 265238 inseminations have been performed during 1967-1994 by different institutions. The average national value for services per conception is 2.4. Mukassa-Mugrwa et al. (1991a) reported that only 1.6% of the cows, that were served with AI at the Gobe Ranch in Ethiopia, calved annually and the postpartum anestrus averaged 304 days. However, a report compiled and released by the Center indicated the average value for non-return rate (NRR) (60-90 days) and number of services per conception for the years from 1992 to 1994 to be 77.1% and 2.68 respectively. The values for NRR ranged from 64% to 86% and that of NSPC ranged from 1.14 to 4.8. section.head: Review of factors affecting dairy cattle productivity in Ethiopia

subsection.head: Milk yield and lactation length
subsection.p:
The lactation milk yield and days in milk of indigenous, crossbred and exotic cattle in Ethiopia reported by previous researchers are compiled in Table 3.2. The milk production potential of indigenous breeds of cattle is very low. In addition, milk production potential of temperate breeds in the tropical environments is higher than the indigenous breeds, but this yield is still far below the genetic potential. Therefore, crossbreeding of the indigenous breeds with temperate exotic breeds has been practiced in the country, since the establishment of the IAR, with the aim of making use of the high genetic potential for milk
production of exotic breeds and the adaptability to the local environment of indigenous breeds.

table.caption: Table 3.2. Milk production performance of indigenous, crossbred and exotic cattle in Ethiopia

legend.p: a= first lactation

subsection.p: In most cases the first cross generation (F 1 ), usually from native dams mated with exotic sires, have been successful. However, further upgrading by back crossing to the temperate breeds were not encouraging. Cunningham (1991) indicated that the possible explanation for the low productivity of F 2 is the idea that blocks of genes giving favorable epistatic effects in the parental breeds and the F 1 may be broken up in the F 2 and subsequent generations.

Heritablity values for milk yield have been estimated to be 25%, 11-26%, 5-7.8%, 9-13% by Funk (1992), Ribas et al. (1999), Ageeb and Hayes (2000) and Mackinnon et al. (1996), respectively. Kiwuwa et al. (1983) reported that breed, parity status and year of calving significantly affect lactation milk yield and length. According to Kiwuwa (1983) indigenous breeds had lower lactation milk yields and lengths than F 1 crosses while crosses of 50% Friesian and 50% Zebu , 50% Friesian and 50% Arsi and 75% Friesian and 25% Zebu had the highest and nearly the same value of milk production. Milk production
also increased with parity status but up to the third lactation. The same results on the effect of parity status on lactation milk yield of Barca breeds (indigenous breeds) kept on station had been reported by Debre Zeit Agricultural Research Center (DZARC) (Goshu, 1981).

The effects of year of calving had been attributed to the change in management and feeding conditions during the years. According to a report by Tawah et al. (1999), lactation performance of pure breed Arsi and crosses with Friesian kept at Assela station in the Arsi region of Ethiopia, was not affected by pre-partum supplementation with concentrate mixes, however, it was significantly and positively affected by postpartum concentrate supplementation. Similarly, a mean increment of milk yield by 35% was also recorded by Little (1987) after supplementation with noug cake (Guizotia abyssinica). The same result was also reported by Kurtu (1999).

subsection.head: Reproductive performance
subsection.p: The reproductive efficiency of a breeding cow is determined by factors like age at first calving, calving interval and number of services per-conception.

block.head: Age at first calving (AFC)
block.p: Age at first calving is closely related to the rearing intensity, and in a breeding program has impact on generation interval and response to selection. Table 3.3 contains the summary of values of age at first calving estimated for different cattle genotypes in Ethiopia.

table.caption: Table 3.3. Summary of values of age at first calving of cattle in the tropics

legend.p: AFC= Age at first calving, a= with natural mating, b= with AI

block.p: Heritability of age at first calving is generally low, indicating that this trait is highly influenced by environmental factors. Cassle (2001) reported a heritability value of 14% for age at first calving in Holstein cattle while Hailemariam (1994) reported a heritability value of 7.5% in Boran cattle in Ethiopia. Trail and Gregory (1981) found no significant difference in AFC between Boran and Sahiwal heifers on a ranch in the Kenya Rift Valley. On the other hand Dennis and Thiongane (1978) reported that Gobra (Senegal Fulani) heifers kept on pasture and fed balanced concentrate supplement calved at earlier age (30 months) than unsupplemented heifers. Moreover, Miranda et al. (1982) and Hailemariam and Kassamersha (1994) found that age at first calving was significantly affected by the year and month of birth in Brazilian Nellore heifers and Ethiopian Boran cows, respectively.

block.head: Calving interval
block.p: Calving interval is probably the best indicator of a cow's reproductive efficiency. Estimates of calving interval in zebu cattle range from 12.2 to 26.6 months (Mukassa-Mugrewa, 1989). Table 3.4 presents some values of calving interval for cattle in Ethiopia estimated by different authors.

Calving interval has a very low heritability. Cassell (2001) reported a heritability value of 3% for first calving interval in Holstein dairy cattle and Hailemariam (1994) reported a heritability value of 3.7% for Boran in Ethiopia. Nutritional conditions that vary seasonally and yearly have major effects on calving interval (Oliveira (1974), Oyedipe (1982) and Hailemariam and Kassamersha (1994)). Calving interval is also influenced by parity. In zebu cattle, calving interval is longest in first calf heifers and older cows and shortest in cows of intermediate age (6-9 years) (Mukassa-Mugrewa, (1989) and Plasse et al., (1972).

block.head: Number of services per-conception (NSPC)
block.p: Number of services per conception depends largely on the breeding system used. It is higher under uncontrolled natural breeding than hand-mating and artificial insemination. Values of NSPC greater than 2 should be regarded as poor (Mukassa-Mugrewa, 1989). Some values of NSPC estimated by different authors in Ethiopia are compiled in Table 3.5.

table.caption: Table 3.5. Summary of values of NSPC for cattle in Ethiopia

legend.p: NSPC= Number of services per conception

block.p:
Heritability of NSPC is low and most of the variation is attributable to environmental factors. Heritability values of 2% was reported for NSPC by Cassell (2001) in Holstein cattle. The work of Hailemariam and Mekonnen (1996) showed that breed and season of conception influence NSPC. Choudhuri et al. (1984) reported that NSPC was significantly
affected by herd, season; that is related to availability of feed, placenta expulsion time, lactation length and milk yield while Sharma and Batnagar (1975) found a significant effect of parity on NSPC in Sahiwal, Red Sindhi and Tharparkar cattle.
Moreover, Azage et al. (1981) found that NSPC was lower for animals from wet areas than those from drier areas in Ethiopia.

section.head: Review of farming system characteristics in the Central Highlands of Ethiopia

subsection.head: Family size and composition
subsection.p: Abdinasir (2000) found a mean household size of 7.9 persons with 61.5% being children in two areas in Arsi. In another region in the Central Highlands of Ethiopia, Niftalem (2000) reported a mean household size of 5.6 persons and 4.6 persons in Inewari and Debre Berhan, respectively, and Getachew et al. (1993) found an average house hold size of 5 persons and 5.6 persons at Dogollo and Inewari, respectively.

subsection.head: Labor distribution
subsection.p: According to Getachew et al. (1993) there is division of labor by gender and age. Livestock husbandry practices are shared among members of the household. According to the work, the responsibility of women includes milking of cows, barn cleaning and dung cake making while men are involved in forage collection and livestock feeding. Herding of livestock is mostly the responsibility of children. This fact is supported by the work of Tekalign et al. (1993) and the final report of MOA and FINNIDA (1996), that was prepared on the activities of the Selale Peasant Dairy Development Pilot Project.

subsection.head: Land holding
subsection.p: The land size allotted to individual farmers by a Peasant Association (PA) as per the Land Reform Declaration of 1975, depended on family size, fertility of the land, the number of PA members and the total land area available within the PA (Getachew et al, 1993). Table 3.6 contains the summary of reports on the land holding of households in the Central Highlands of Ethiopia.

Abdinasir (2000) reported significant effects of farm size, cattle holding and sheep holding on the cultivated land size. This work indicated that cultivated land size increased with farm size at Bilalo and Lemmu and households that own less than 5 TLU of cattle,
cultivated less area than those with larger cattle holding in Bilalo. In addition, households with one or less TLU of sheep holding, cultivated less area than those with larger sheep holdings. Niftalem (2000) also reported that cultivated land size significantly increased with farm size.

subsection.head: Crop yield
subsection.p: Tekalign et al. (1993) reported that the annual cereal (teff, wheat and barley) production in the Central Ethiopian Highlands to be 13.2q/ha out of which 10q, 1.65q and 1.55q are consumed by the household, used as seed and sold, respectively. Another work carried out by Getachew et al. (1993) indicated that the annual cereal (wheat and teff) production at Inewari was 16.8q/ha. Abdinasir (2000) reported that the annual grain productions were 14.8q/ha and 16.9q/ha at Bilalo and Lemmu, respectively.

subsection.head: Objectives of livestock keeping
subsection.p:
The most important objective of keeping livestock in the Ethiopian highlands is the use of oxen as draught animals (Tekalign et al, 1993 and Getachew et al, 1993). Milk, meat and hides are relatively less important byproducts. In addition, manure is collected, dried and used as a major household fuel. Cows are kept to produce oxen needed for draught and are also milked with the milk being consumed mostly by young children. Surplus milk and other livestock products are often sold to finance the purchase of basic household commodities (Tekalign et al, 1993). Sheep are economically important in the highlands in
that they are sources of investment, security and cash (Getachew et al, 1993). Equines are kept mainly for packing and transporting purposes (Tekalign et al, 1993).

subsection.head: Livestock and cattle herd composition
subsection.p: Table 3.7 presents summary of values of livestock holdings per household in the Central Highlands of Ethiopia. Cattle comprised most of the livestock herd while sheep are the second most important species of livestock in most of the areas. (Tekalign et al. (1993), Abdinasir (2000), MOA and FINNIDA (1996)). Niftalem (2000) has indicated that family size has a significant effect on livestock herd size.
