subsection.p: The work of Abdinasir (2000) indicated that the mean value for cattle herd size at Bilalo and Lemmu areas are 8.57 TLU and 10.38 TLU respectively. According to his work the herd was dominated by oxen that comprised 43.2% of the herd followed by cows that comprise 30.3% of the herd. A similar result was found by Tekalign et al. (1993) who reported that oxen and cows comprise 43.87% and 21.93% of the herd at Ada, respectively. According to the final report of the MOA and FINNIDA (1996) on the activities of the Selale Peasant Dairy Development Pilot Project, cows comprised only 11.2% of the cattle herd at Selale area. Abdinasir (2000) indicated that herd size increases significantly with household size, cultivated area and grazing area.

subsection.head: Livestock feeding
subsection.p: In Ethiopia, native pasture is the major source of feed for ruminants both is the area of mixed farming system and pastoralism, although it is neither quantitatively nor qualitatively adequate to support profitable animal production (Seyom et al, 1997). Abdinasir (2000) indicated that in Arsi area the average grazing hours during the rainy and dry seasons were 10 and 9 hours respectively.

In addition, teff and wheat straws are also important sources of livestock feed in the highland Vertisol areas. Barley and oat straws are also important in areas where they are produced. Straw supplementation is commonly restricted to work-oxen and lactating cows. But grass hay is commonly fed to working oxen and milking cows during the dry season. The amount of straw fed depends on the work expected from the ox. During the peak period, on average 5 to 10 kg of straw is fed to an ox each day (Getachew et al, 1993).

Since concentrate supplements are not readily available and are relatively expensive, they are rarely used in animal production (Solomon and Solomon, 1995). Instead, on-farm grown forage legumes are suggested as good alternatives (Nnadi and Haque, 1988, ESAP, 1999). However, the various milling by-products obtained from processing wheat and oil seed meals are of high demand as livestock feed for state farms, city dairy holders, and to a lesser extent for small dairy cooperatives (Alemayehu, 1995). Molasses, obtained from the sugar industry in Ethiopia, is being used mainly by beef producers and to some extent by dairy producers in and around the major cities.

Farmers at Selale area were found to have three main feed resources; grazing, hay and straw that supply a minimum of 90% of the total dry matter intake. In addition, it was reported that grazing was practiced by 95% of the project contact farmers and 90% of the cows grazed on average 6.6 hours per day. Supplementation with straw was practiced mainly during the long rainy season between June and August (MOA and FINNIDA, 1996).

subsection.head: Livestock housing
subsection.p: The traditional livestock husbandry practiced across the Ethiopian highlands is similar. Livestock are kept in a 'kraal' during the night. During the day time, they are herded on communal pasture, private grazing lands or in a stubble depending on the season (Getachew et al, 1993). Improved type of housing using barns constructed from locally available and cheap materials is being practiced mainly by urban and peri-urban small holder dairy farmers owning crossbred dairy cattle.

section.head: Status of Brucellosis in Ethiopia
section.p:
Infections of the bovine genital tract affect fertility by altering its environment, so that there may be impaired sperm transport, sperm death or embryonic and fetal deaths.
Venereal diseases are among these genital tract infections that are transmissible through mating. Brucellosis is one of the most important venereal diseases in that it causes abortion and significantly impairs fertility. The disease also causes reduction in milk production. Further importance of the disease include its public health significance and unfavorable effect on export trade of livestock products.

The fact that it is transmissible through natural service and the traditional management systems use indiscriminately locally available bulls for breeding makes it more important than other infectious causes of infertility.

A summary of values of the prevalence of Brucellosis in Ethiopia is presented in Table 3.8. The disease seems to be more prevalent in improved breeds than in locals (Abebe, 1989). In addition, Yilkal (1998) reported that the prevalence was significantly higher in farms that keep more than 100 animals (9.3%) than in those that keep less than 50 animals (3.3%). Jiwa et al. (1996) reported higher prevalence rate in dairy (6.3%) and ranch animals (15.5%) than in animals kept under extensive grazing conditions (4.3%) in the Lake Victoria Zone of Tanzania.

subsection.head: Addis Ababa /the Addis Milkshed (urban and peri-urban setting)
subsection.p: Addis Ababa, the capital of Ethiopia, lies between 8 o 55’ and 9 o 07’ north and 38 o 40’ and 38 o 50’ east situated in the center of a well drained plateau and surrounded by hills and mountains, between 2000 meters and 3000 meters above sea level (Figure 4.1.). The rainy season extends from Mid-June to Late-September with an annual average rainfall of 1000mm. The average annual daily temperature is 16 o c. The city covers an extensive area of 216 km 2 and has a population of more than 3 million inhabitants. According to a recent census undertaken by the Addis Ababa Region Agricultural Bureau (1996) a total of 5167 small, medium and large dairy farms are found and 34649450 liters of milk are produced annually. A total of 37426 local and crossbred cows are available within the region out of which 20% are indigenous and 46.5% are crossbred.

subsection.head: Selale(rural setting)
subsection.p: Selale is a common name for the area that is currently the Northwest Shoa Zone of the Oromia Regional Administration in Ethiopia. It is located 190 km north west of Addis Ababa (Figure 4.1). It covers 1174500 ha of land from which 40% is crop land, 25% is grazing land, 13% is forest and bush area, 7% is construction area and 15% is unproductive land. The human population in the area is 1242366 . There are 210215 households in the region that practice predominantly mixed farming. The cattle population is about 1113200. 42% of the area is highland that is suitable for crop cultivation and livestock husbandry and the herd structure is characterized by a higher number of cows. The lowland area constitutes 35% and farming activities represent the largest part of the small holders income. The herd structure in the lowland areas is thus dominated by oxen. Selale has 2 annual rainy seasons: from February-May (short rainy season) and from June-October (long rainy season) (Tittarelli, F, 1990).

This study concentrates on the highland parts of Selale, with an altitude over 2800 meters above sea level considered to be a high potential cereal-livestock zones where dairy activities play a significant role in the livelihood of farmers in the area. Considering the potential of the area and the economic significance of dairy production to the local
community there have been repeated efforts by governmental and non-governmental aid organizations to improve the dairy productivity. This area has also better access to livestock development services (governmental and non-governmental) and milk markets than other rural areas. Due to the above mentioned reasons and the economic capacity of the peasants small-holder dairy production with crossbred dairy cattle is a common practice in the area.

section.head: Sampling procedures
section.p:
A total of 120 dairy cow owners and 20 breeding bull owners were included in this study. 80 of the dairy cow owners and all the breeding bull owners were selected from the North-West-Shoa Zone (commonly called Selale ) of the Oromia Region. Two Woredas (administrative units) namely Mulo-Sululta and
Degem and two peasant associations (PA) of each Woreda were selected randomly. All the contact farmers of the SDDP available in each PA were included in the sample while a random selection has been performed to select farmers that are not direct beneficiaries of the SDDP. The random selection was done from the list of farmers available at the Zonal Agricultural Office. 40 dairy cow owners were selected randomly from Addis Ababa. The North-East zone of the capital, that includes areas that are commonly called Shola and Kaliti, was selected. The random selection was done from the list of dairy cow owners available at the Zonal Agricultural Office. 25 small scale, 8 medium scale and 7 large scale dairy farms were selected in an attempt to include all levels of dairy production in Addis Ababa. subsection.head: Questionnaire survey
subsection.p: Detailed structured questionnaires (see annex) were prepared and used to collect information from dairy cow and b7reeding bull owners in a one visit interview. The questionnaires were pre-tested to check clarity and appropriateness of the questions. Some of the information collected through interview were supported by observation.

The data collected through interview are classified as follow: farming system characteristics, estimated performance of dairy cattle owned by the farm, breeding practices by farmers, natural mating organization and farm incidences of abortion and awareness of farmers on venereal disease.

Farming system characteristics : information on family status, level of education of farmers, family size and composition, land holding, crop yield per hectare, livestock herd size and composition, cattle herd size and composition, objectives of dairying, dairy cattle feeding, dairy cattle management and constraints of dairying and labor distribution were collected.

Estimated performances of dairy cattle owned : information were collected on estimated daily milk yield at the beginning, middle and end of lactation, lactation length, age at first calving, calving interval and services per-conception.

Breeding practices by dairy cow and breeding bull owners : information concerning farmers' opinion concerning the preferred performance traits, sources of information to acquire dairy cows and options preferred to improve dairy productivity were collected.

Organization and efficiency of bull mating : information pertaining sources and use pattern of breeding bulls, management of bulls, number of farms getting bull service, number of cows getting the bull service, number of first, second and third services; time required to go to the bull station, times of service, price of bull service per-conception, mating record keeping, non-return rate and number of offspring obtained were collected.

Awareness of farmers on venereal diseases prevalence, prevention and control : information concerning the awareness of farmers on the risk of venereal diseases, knowledge of farmers on the name and symptoms of diseases, farm incidences of abortion and prevention and control activities by farmers were collected.

subsection.head: Secondary data collection from the National Artificial Insemination Center
subsection.p: Information collected through personal communication with responsible AI personnel to describe the organization of AI at a national level and to analyze AI efficiency in Addis Ababa included breed and age of breeding bulls owned by the center, time and source of replacement bulls, feeding and housing of breeding bulls, selection of breeding bulls, performance testing and incidence and control of venereal diseases, cost of production per semen straw and price of AI service per-conception.

Data recorded by the Center for the last five years were also used as a source of information for number of semen straws produced per year, number of semen straws discarded per year, semen quality parameters and number of first, second, third and fourth inseminations performed per year (for Addis Ababa) and non-return rates (for Addis Ababa).

subsection.head: Disease prevalence tests
subsection.p: Blood samples were collected from all the dairy cows (713) and breeding bulls (20) owned by the farmers included in this study and all breeding bulls owned and that are currently used for semen collection (14) by the National AI Center. The blood samples were collected using 9 ml Serum-vacutainer-tubes, that are coated with clot activator, and 20G double end needles. The blood samples were let to stand for some time till they clot and 25 ul of serum was taken from each sample and mixed with 25 ul of Rose-Bengal Antigen on a Serum Agglutination Plate for Serum Agglutination Test. The mixture were checked for any level of serum agglutination that is considered to be positive.

subsection.head: Family size
subsection.p: Data concerning family size were collected for the number of sons and daughters at different ages. The family size was, thus, calculated as the total sum of the number of sons, number of daughters, farmer and spouse.

subsection.head: Crop yield per hectare
subsection.p: Data were collected for the amount of teff, wheat and barley produced in the year immediately before the study year (Februray 2000-January2001). Crop yield per hectare was, therefore, the sum of the amount of grains (teff, wheat and barley) that were produced by the household per hectare the year immediately before the study year (1999/2000) and it is expressed in tones.

subsection.head: Livestock number
subsection.p: Data were collected for the number of the different species of livestock that were owned by the household. The total number of livestock owned by the household was, therefore, the sum of the converted values in TLU of the number of all species of livestock owned by the farmer, excluding chicken. The factors indicated in Table 4.4 were used to convert the number of the different species of livestock into TLU.

subsection.head: Estimated daily milk yield and lactation length
subsection.p:
Since the research was based on a one-visit interview, it was not possible to record milk yield at intervals, rather farmers were asked for the quantity of milk they milked from their cows during previous lactation periods at the beginning, at the middle and at the end of lactation. Daily milk yield at the beginning of lactation refers to the quantity of milk in liters the farmers milked daily from a cow during the first two to three months of lactation, daily milk yield in the middle of lactation refers to the quantity of milk the farmers milked daily from a cow for the next six months and daily milk yield at the end of lactation refers to the quantity of milk the farmers milked daily from a cow during the remaining months. In addition, the values for lactation length were recorded in months since most of the
farmers didn’t have records and it was difficult for them to recall the lactation length in days.

subsection.head: Estimated reproductive performances
subsection.p:
Age at first calving was determined
from information on birth date and the time of first calving of their cows. Calving interval was calculated from information obtained on times of previous calving and last calving. Number of services per conception
represented the
number of services required for the cow's last pregnancy.

block.head: Dairy cattle feeding
block.p:
Table 5.4 contains the values for the amount of different types of feed stuff given to livestock at the different study areas. As it can be seen in the table, dairy cattle was spending more than half of the day time on grazing at Mulo-Sululta and Degem. In Addis Ababa, 97.5% of the herds did not graze at all. The highest amount of crop residue was supplied to dairy cattle at Degem followed by Mulo-Sululta while no farm in Addis Ababa supplied crop residues. In general, farms at Mulo-Sululta and Degem supplement their dairy cows with a very small quantity of wheat bran and oil seed meal. At Mulo-Sululta and Degem only 12.5% and 2.5% of the households supplement wheat bran, respectively, while 25% and 97.5% of the farms at Mulo-Sululta and Degem supplement oilseed meal, respectively. The quantity of oilseed meal supplemented was larger than that of wheat bran at Selale area. In Addis Ababa, dairy cattle were supplemented with relatively large quantities of wheat bran and oilseed meals. The quantity of hay given to dairy cattle in
Addis Ababa was almost double that of Mulo-Sululta and Degem. Atela , that is a byproduct of local beverage processing, was being supplemented only at Mulo-Sululta and Degem.

block.p: On average a total of 6.87 kg, 8.33 kg and 10.76 kg of feed (DM) were supplied daily to dairy cows at Mulo-Sululta, Degem and Addis Abeba, respectively. Most of the feed (DM) supplied originated at Selale from natural pasture hay (43.7%) and crop residues (40.4%) while in Addis Ababa 62% and 38% of the feed (DM) originated from natural pasture hay and concentrates.

Table 5.5 contains the estimated amount of metabolizable energy (MJ) and crude protein (g) required (maintenance and production) and supplied per day per cow from natural pasture hay, oilseed meals and wheat bran. At Mulo-Sululta, 97.5% of the metabolizable energy and 127% of the crude protein requirement of cows owned by "SDDP contact farmers" were fulfilled while 71% of the metabolizable energy and 72% of the crude protein requirements of cows of "SDDP follow farmers" were supplied. At Degem, 97.5% of the metabolizable energy requirement and 139% of the crude protein requirement of cows of "SDDP contact farmers" and 83.9% of the metabolizable energy requirement and 96.9% of the crude protein requirement of cows of "SDDP follow farmers" were supplied.

In Addis Ababa, 90.7%, 93.5% and 93.1% of the metabolizable energy requirement of cows of small scale, medium scale and large scale farms, respectively, were provided. In addition, 117%, 116% and 123% of the Crude Protein requirements of cows of small scale, medium scale and large scale farms, respectively, were included in the ration.

block.head: Objectives of dairying
block.p: In the two woredas at Selale the main objective of keeping dairy cattle was to obtain income and provide food to the household. 92.9% of "SDDP contact farmers" and 64.4% of "SDDP follow farmers" at Mulo-Sululta and 88.2% of "SDDP contact farmers" and 91.3% of "SDDP follow farmers" at Degem said that they produced milk as a source of income and for household consumption. The remaining percentage of households in both areas said that they produce milk only for household consumption. In both areas all the households sold their milk to the dairy development enterprise for a price of 1.25 birr (0.15 EUR).

In Addis Ababa, the objective of keeping dairy cattle was mainly to obtain income. However, 92.8% of the small scale dairy farm owners said they produce milk for sale and household consumption. The price of milk in Addis Ababa varies from birr 2.50 to 2.75 per liter of milk and the market in Addis Ababa was more diversified including the DDE, individuals in the neighborhood and restaurants.

block.head: Dairy cattle management
block.p:
All "SDDP contact farmers" at Mulo-Sululta and Degem and 38.5% and 47.8% of "SDDP follow farmers" at Mulo-Sululta and Degem, respectively, kept their dairy cattle in barns that were well constructed from locally available materials. 57.7% and 39.1% of "SDDP
follow farmers" at Mulo-Sululta and Degem, respectively, kept their dairy cattle in corrals constructed near by the farmers house. The remaining small percentages of "SDDP follow farmers" both at Mulo-Sululta and Degem kept their dairy cattle in an open field and within the farmers house.

In addition, all "SDDP contact farmers" and 96.2% of " SDDP follow farmers" at Mulo-Sululta practiced a management based on partial grazing in which dairy cattle graze in the morning and spent the rest of the day and the night within their barns or corrals. At Degem, 94.1% of "SDDP contact farmers" and 82.6% of "SDDP follow farmers" practiced the same type of management, however, dairy cows spent much of their time in their barns or near the farmers house.

In Addis Ababa, 84% of small scale farms and all of the medium scale and large scale farms had barns. Most of the barns of the small scale and medium scale farms were constructed within the living compound of the households and, thus, were small and crowded. However, most of the large scale farms had a separate farm compound usually at the outskirts of the city and had well constructed and modern types of barns. 92.0%, 71.4% and 83.3% of small scale, medium scale and large scale farms, respectively, practiced a management system based on stall feeding with zero grazing.

block.head: Constraints of dairy production
block.p: Table 5.6 contains the percentages of the households that mentioned some constraints of dairy production at Selale area. Lack of livestock feed and livestock diseases were the most important constraints for "SDDP contact farmers" at Mulo-Sululta and Degem. On the other hand, livestock diseases were the most important constraints for "SDDP follow farmers" at Mulo-Suluta. At Degem, more than half of "SDDP contact farmers" found also the low genetic potential of dairy cows and lack of veterinary services as constraints. In addition, lack of livestock feed, livestock diseases, low genetic potential of dairy cows and lack of veterinary services were stressed as constraints by most of the households that are "SDDP follow farmers" at Degem.

In Addis Ababa, lack of livestock feed was mentioned as the most important constraint by all the farm scales. 92%, 85.7% and 83.3% of the small scale, medium scale and large scale farms, respectively, mentioned lack of livestock feed as a constraint. Disease was the
second most important constraint that was mentioned by 68%, 57.1% and 83.3% of the small scale, medium scale and large scale farms respectively. A significant percentage of small scale farms (32%) also considered lack of labor as a constraint. Lack of veterinary service was mentioned as a constraint only by small scale farms (12%) while lack of livestock development services was mentioned only by medium scale (28.6%) and small scale (16%) farms.

block.head: Labor distribution
block.p: In 85.7%, 78.6%, 85.7% and 85.7% of the households of "SDDP contact farmers" in Mulo-Sululta, the husbands were responsible for feeding, milking, breeding and health monitoring, respectively. Wives were responsible for herding in 71.4% of the households of "SDDP contact farmers". In "SDDP follow farmers", husbands were involved in 46.2% of the households in feeding and in 65.4% of all the households in milking, breeding, health monitoring and stable work. In this case, wives shared responsibilities for feeding (34.6%), breeding (26.9%), health monitoring (19.2%) and housing (26.9%) with husbands that had still the largest share of responsibility in all of the activities. Wives were also responsible for herding in most of the households of "SDDP follow farmers" (53.8%).

At Degem, the proportions of responsibilities were almost the same as in Mulo-Sululta. In the households of "SDDP contact farmers" and "SDDP follow farmers", all responsibilities except herding were that of the husband. In most of the households, herding was the responsibility of wives.

In Addis Ababa, in all of the large scale and medium scale farms and 60% of the small scale farms feeding of the dairy cattle was done by hired laborers. In more than 80% of the households of medium and large scale dairy farms, sons of the farmers were engaged with milking, breeding, health monitoring and stable work. In small scale dairy farms, the practices of milking and breeding were shared almost equally between husbands (36%) and sons (44%) and while husbands (64.4%) had the responsibility of health monitoring. Wives (32%) shared the stable work with sons (40%).

Factors included in Table 5.25 are affiliation to SDDP, crop yield per hectare, grazing land size, herd size and the genotype of dairy cows. The results indicated that affiliation to SDDP significantly affected estimated daily milk yield, at the middle of lactation (p<0.05) and lactation length (p<0.05) while crop yield per hectare affected estimated daily milk yield at the beginning and middle of lactation (p<0.001) and lactation length (p<0.01).

subsection.head: Sources of information for acquisition of dairy cows and breeding bulls by farmers
subsection.p: Figure 5.7 contains the overall proportions of farmers that mentioned different sources of information for acquisition of dairy cattle at the different study areas. Most of the farmers at Mulo-Sululta (95%), Degem (82.5%) and Addis Ababa (75%) used individual performance information to acquire dairy cows. The second most important source of information mentioned by the farmers was the performance of the progeny of the cows at Mulo-Sululta (12.5%) and the performance of the dam of the cow at Degem (80%) and Addis Ababa (42.5%).

The results of chi-square statistics revealed that there was a significant variation between the study areas (p<0.001) concerning the source of information to acquire dairy cattle. However, there were no significant variations between the two affiliation groups at Selale and the three farm scales in Addis Ababa (p>0.05). Table 5.37 contains proportion of farmers at all the study areas using one or a combination of sources of information sources. Most of the farmers at Mulo-Sululta (87.5%) and Addis Ababa (57.5%) used only
individual performance. At Degem, 57.5% of the farmers considered individual performance, dam's performance and progeny performance together.

In the case of bulls, 84.7% of the bull owners at Mulo-Sululta and all the bull owners at Degem used dam performance as a source of information for acquisition of breeding bulls. The remaining proportion of farmers at Mulo-sululta used progeny performance. However, the variations between the study areas and the two affiliation groups were not significant (p>0.05).

table.caption: Table 5.37. The use of one or more sources of information sources by farmers at all the study areas for performance identification (% of farmers).

block.head: Preferred performance traits by dairy cow owners
block.p: Figure 5.8 shows the proportions of farmers at all the study areas that mentioned different performance traits as their preferences. The most important preferred trait mentioned by farmers in all the study areas was high daily milk yield. It was mentioned by 97.5% of the farmers at Mulo-Sululta and Degem and by 92.5% of the farmers in Addis Ababa. High daily milk yield was followed by high fat content at Mulo-Sululta (60%), shorter age at first calving at Degem (55%) and Addis Ababa (42.5%). The third most frequently preferred trait was shorter age at first calving at Mulo-Sululta (35%), high fat content at Degem (20%) and longer lactation length in Addis Ababa (40%). The least considered performance trait was shorter calving interval at Mulo-Sululta (30%), Degem (17.5%) and Addis Ababa (5%).

mm.caption: Figure 5.8. Preferred performance traits mentioned by dairy cow owners at all the study areas

block.p: With regard to the first priority performance traits, the results of chi-square statistics showed that there was no significant variation between the study areas and the affiliated groups (p>0.05). 97.5% of the farmers at Mulo-Sululta, 95% of the farmers at Degem and 90% of the farmers in Addis Ababa put high milk yield as the first priority performance trait. However, there was a significant variation between the three farm scales in Addis Ababa since a significant proportion of the large scale farms (42.9%) put longer lactation length as the first priority performance trait (p<0.01).

There was a significant variation between the study areas (p<0.001) concerning second priority performance traits. Table 5.38 contains the proportions of farmers that mentioned different second priority performance traits.

table.caption: Table 5.38. Second priority performance traits mentioned by farmers at all the study areas

block.p: A considerable proportion of the farmers considered high fat content (39.5%) and longer lactation length (31.6%) at Mulo-Sululta, shorter age at first calving (54.5%) at Degem and longer lactation length(40%) in Addis Ababa as the second priority performance trait. There were no significant variations between the two affiliation groups at Selale and the three farm scales in Addis Ababa (p>0.05).

Morphological characteristics that are considered to be related to dairy cows productivity and mentioned by farmers are shown in Figure 5.9. Small head size in relation to the overall body size was mentioned by most of the farmers at Mulo-Sululta (72.5%) and in Addis Ababa (77.5%). At Degem, almost all the farmers (95%) considered a cow as best for milk production if it has a straight back. At Mulo-Sululta, triangular shape of the frame of a cow and straightness of the back of the cow was also considered by 32.5% and 5% of the farmers, respectively. At Degem, the second most important morphological characteristic considered was large udder of the cow (42.5%) followed by small head of the cow (15%) and triangular shape of the frame of the cow (12.5%). In Addis Ababa, the second most important morphological characteristic mentioned was straightness of the back of cows (45%) followed by triangular shape of the frame of the cow (15%) and large udder (12.5%).

block.head: Preferred performance traits for breeding bulls
block.p: 57.1% of the bull owners at Mulo-Sululta and 16.7% of the bull owners at Degem had the chance to select their own bulls. With respect to affiliation to SDDP, 90.9% of the "SDDP contact farmers" did not select their own bulls, which was provided by SDDP, while all the "SDDP follow farmers" selected their own bulls. A chi-square statistics result showed that, the differences between the study areas was not significant (p>0.05) while the difference between the affiliation groups was significant (p<0.001).

Figure 5.10 contains the percentages of bull owners mentioning different preferred performance traits at Selale. All the bull owners both at Mulo-Sululta (100%) and Degem (100%) considered high daily milk yield as the most important preferred performance trait followed by high fat content at Mulo-Sululta (71.4%) and shorter age at first calving and calving interval at Degem ( 50%). Shorter age at first calving and high fat content were the third most important selection criteria mentioned at Mulo-Sululta (50%) and Degem (33.3%) respectively.

mm.caption: Figure 5.10. Preferred performance traits mentioned by bull owners at Selale area

block.p:
Concerning the priority of performance traits, 61.5% of the bull owners at Mulo-Sululta and 66.7% of the bull owners at Degem considered high daily milk yield as the first priority performance trait while the remaining proportion at both areas put high fat content.
The result of the chi-square statistics showed that there were no significant variations between the study areas and the two affiliation groups (p>0.05).

Half of the bull owners at Degem (50%) considered high fat content and shorter age at first calving as the second priority performance trait while 57.1% and 42.9% and of the bull owners at Mulo-Sululta put longer lactation length and high fat content as the second priority performance trait, respectively. However, the result of Chi-square statistics indicated that there were no significant variations between the study areas and the two affiliation groups (p>0.05).

subsection.head: Options preferred by individual farmers to improve dairy productivity

block.head: Options preferred for increased milk production
block.p: 52.5%, 55% and 65% of the farmers at Mulo-Sululta, Degem and Addis Ababa, respectively, planned to attain higher milk yield through the introduction of cross breeds with higher exotic blood into their herd. A significant proportion of the farmers at Mulo-Sululta (45%), Degem (35%) and Addis Ababa (27.5%) were satisfied with the existing exotic blood level. The remaining small proportions in all the study areas wanted to introduce exotic breeds into their dairy herd to get high milk yield. The results of chi-square statistics indicated that there were no significance variations between the study areas and the two affiliation groups concerning their plan to attain a higher milk yield (p>0.05).

There was a significant (p<0.01) variation between the three farm scales in Addis Ababa concerning options preferred by farmers to improve the productivity of dairy cattle. Most of the large scale farms (85.7%) were satisfied with the existing exotic blood level while most of the small scale (76.9%) and medium scale (85.7%) farms had the plan to introduce dairy cows with higher exotic blood (Figure 5. 11).

Most of the farmers that were satisfied with the existing exotic blood level (90.7%), nearly half of the farmers that planned to introduce high grade dairy cows (47.8%) and more than half of the farmers that planned to introduce exotic cows (62.5%), emphasized that the success of their plans depend primarily on the availability of feed stuffs, specially concentrates.

mm.caption: Figure 5.11. Options preferred by farmers to attain higher milk yield in Addis Ababa

block.head: Options preferred to improve reproductive performance
block.p: Almost all the farmers at Mulo-Sululta (97.5%) did not have plans of using either exotic breed cows or high grade cows to attain a shorter age at first calving. They believed that age at first calving could be improved with improved nutrition. However, 77.8% of the farmers at Degem and 85.7% of the farmers in Addis Ababa planned to improve the age at first calving of their dairy cattle herd through the introduction of high grade cows into their farms. The remaining proportions of farmers at Degem and in Addis Ababa planned to introduce exotic breeds while those of Mulo-Sululta planned to introduce high grade cows into their farms. Furthermore, all the farmers at all the study areas regardless of the options they preferred, emphasized the necessity of availability of feed, specially concentrates for their plan to succeed. A chi-square statistics result showed that there was a significant variation between the study areas concerning options preferred to attain a shorter age at first calving (p<0.001). However, there were no significant variation between the affiliation groups and farm scales (p>0.05).

Concerning options preferred by farmers to improve calving interval, there was a significant variation between the different study areas (p<0.001) and the affiliation groups (p<0.05). However, there was no significant variation between the farm scales (p>0.05). 95%, 42.5% and 57.5% of the farmers at Mulo-Sululta, Degem and Addis Ababa, respectively, believed that the calving interval could be improved through improved
feeding. The remaining proportion of farmers at all the study areas preferred the use of high grade cows to reduce calving interval.

Most of the "SDDP follow farmers" (77.6%) believed that the calving interval could be improved through improved feeding while only 54.8% of the "SDDP contact farmers" believed so. The remaining proportion of farmers in both cases preferred the use of high grade cows to improve calving interval.

section.head: Organization and efficiency of natural mating and artificial insemination

block.head: The existing pattern of mating practices
block.p: There was a significant difference between the three study areas in the existing pattern of mating practices (p<0.001). Most of the farmers both at Mulo-Sululta (90) and Degem (85%) were using only natural mating while the remaining proportion of farmers at Mulo-Sululta and Degem used both AI and natural service alternatively (Figure 5. 12). There was also a significant difference (p<0.05) between the "SDDP contact farmers" and "SDDP follow farmers" at Selale area in that 77.4% of the "SDDP contact farmers" and 93.9% of the "SDDP follow farmers" used natural mating while 22.6% of the "SDDP contact farmers" and 6.1% of the "SDDP follow farmers" used both natural mating and AI.

In Addis Ababa, 75% of the farmers used only AI and 17.5% of the farmers used only natural mating while the remaining proportion of farmers (7.5%) used both AI and natural mating alternatively (Figure 5.12). Differences in the existing pattern of mating practices were not significant between the farm scales in Addis Ababa.

mm.caption: Figure 5.12. The existing pattern of mating practices in the different study areas

block.p: Regarding the reason for the type of mating practice used, a chi-square result indicated that there was a significant difference (p<0.05) between the different study areas. More than half of the farmers at Mulo-Sululta (62.5%) and in Addis Ababa (66.7%), and three fourth (74.5%) of the farmers at Degem used natural mating because it was easily accessible. On the other hand, a significant proportion of farmers at Mulo-Sululta (32.5%) and some farmers in Addis Ababa (13.3%) and at Degem (7.5%) used natural mating because of familiarity. There was also a significant variation (p<0.05) between the two affiliation groups at Selale in that 6.5% of the "SDDP contact farmers" and 29.2% of the "SDDP follow farmers" used natural mating due to their familiarity to the service. However, there was no significant difference between the different farm scales in Addis Ababa regarding reasons for the use of mating practices (p>0.05).

The most important reasons mentioned, for using AI in Addis Ababa include the belief that AI provides semen from bulls specifically selected for milk production (43.3%), accessibility of AI (23.3%), familiarity with AI (16.7%), and lack of alternatives (13.2%). The remaining 3.3% of the farmers believed that AI is cheaper than natural mating.

block.head: Times of service and season of mating
block.p:
The results of chi-square statistics showed that time of service for heats detected in the morning was affected significantly by the study areas (p<0.001). 95% of the farmers at Mulo-Sululta, 74.4% of the farmers at Degem and 42.9% of farmers in Addis Ababa take
their cows for natural mating during the same morning heat is detected while all the other farmers do it in the afternoon.

When heat signs were detected in the afternoon, 95% of the farmers at Mulo-Sululta, 43.6% of the farmers at Degem and 14.3% of the farmers in Addis Ababa take their cows in the same afternoon for natural mating and all other farmers in the next morning. The variation between the study areas was significant (p<0.001).

With regard to times of service using AI in Addis Ababa, 23.3% of the farmers could get AI service in the same morning of heat detection while 73.3% of them could get AI service in the afternoon. If cows were detected in heat during the afternoon, 20% of the farmers could get the service the same afternoon while 80% would get AI service the next morning. There was no variation between farm scales (p>0.05).

Some farmers from Degem (25.6%) and Addis Ababa (35%), mentioned seasonal preferences to mate their dairy cattle while farmers at Mulo-Sululta had no preference (p<0.05). There was also a significant (p<0.01) variation only between the study areas with regard to the season preferred and the reasons for season preference (p<0.05). All the farmers at Degem preferred the long rainy season while in Addis Ababa most of the farmers (75%) preferred the beginning of the dry season and some (25%) preferred the short rainy season. The farmers at Degem and some farmers in Addis Ababa (21.4%) mentioned availability of feed as reason while most of the farmers in Addis Ababa (71.4%) wanted to avoid an overlapping of the peak milk yield period with the fasting season of the Ethiopian Orthodox Christians (between February and April) during which people do not eat animal products.

block.head: Mating management and record keeping
block.p:
The result of chi-square statistics indicated that there was a significant variation (p<0.01) between the different study areas regarding the proportion of farmers having knowledge about bulls serving their cows. All the farmers at Degem and most of the farmers (82.5) at Mulo-Sululta and in Addis Ababa (70%) had knowledge about the performance of the bull serving their cow. The variations between the two affiliation groups at Selale and the three farm scales in Addis Ababa were not significant. However, all farmers using AI had
limited knowledge about the AI bulls used except the belief that AI provides semen from bulls specifically selected for milk production.

Concerning mating confirmation, the result of chi-square test showed that there were significant variations between the study areas (p<0.001) and the two affiliation groups at Selale (p<0.01). 92.3% of the farmers at Degem and 70% of the farmers in Addis Ababa using natural mating confirm the mating. However, at Mulo-Sululta only half of the farmers (50%) were doing the same. 93.5% of the "SDDP contact farmers" and 56.3% of the "SDDP follow farmers" were confirming mating. There was no significant variation between the different farm scales in Addis Ababa regarding confirmation of mating (p>0.05).

In addition, there were significant variations between the study areas (p<0.001) and the two affiliation groups at Selale (p<0.001) regarding the proportion of farmers keeping records. Most of the farmers at Degem (75%) and in Addis Ababa (87.5%) and less than half of the farmers at Mulo-Sululta (45%), had mating records. Most of the "SDDP contact farmers" (93.5%) had mating records while a significant portion of "SDDP follow farmers" (39.6%) did not have mating records. All the farmers that used natural mating kept only records of time of service, mostly based on recalling, while those farmers that used AI in Addis Ababa wrote records including times of heat on-set and times of service. There was no significant variation between the three farm scales in Addis Ababa (p>0.05).

block.head: Satisfaction with services
block.p: 97.5% of the farmers at Mulo-Sululta, 92.5% of the farmers at Degem and 81.8% of the farmers using natural mating in Addis Ababa said they had not so far encountered any problem with getting natural service. All the farmers that said they had a problem with the natural mating relate it to the poor libido of the bulls. In Addis Ababa, nearly half of the farmers using AI (46.7%) said they had problem with AI. More than 93% of these farmers said the AI service was not reliable in that the inseminators were not punctual. The chi-square statistics result regarding problems associated with breeding methods used indicated that there was no significant difference between the study areas, the two affiliation groups at Selale and the three farm scales in Addis Ababa (p>0.05).

All the farmers at Mulo-Sululta, 89.7% of the farmers at Degem and 90% of the farmers in Addis Ababa using bull service, without any significant variation between the study areas, the two affiliation groups at Selale, and the three farm scales in Addis Ababa (p>0.05), were satisfied with the bull service they were getting. However, half of the farmers in Addis Ababa using only AI (50%) said they were not satisfied with the AI service and thus 33.3% of all the farmers looked for the alternative of using natural mating.

subsection.head: Analyses of organization and efficiency of natural mating

block.head: Bull ownership
block.p: All the the bull owners at Degem kept bulls as a source of income. However, bull owners at Mulo-Sululta had diversified objectives of bull keeping. 42.9% of them kept bulls as a source of income while the same percentage of farmers kept bulls both for mating purpose within their own farm and also for draught purposes. The remaining bull owners at Mulo-Sululta (14.3%) kept bulls only for in-farm mating uses. Differences between the study areas and the affiliation groups at Selale were significant (p<0.001).

In addition, there was no significant (p>0.05) variation between the study areas regarding the breed composition of bulls in the areas. 72.7% of the bulls belonging to the "SDDP contact farmers" were pure Friesian while 18.2% were 50% Friesian crosses and a few were indigenous. 22.1 % of the "SDDP follow farmers" used pure Friesian and 77.8% used 75% Friesian crossbred bulls. "SDDP follow farmers" obtained bulls from individuals owning dairy cows in the village and the surrounding areas and the average price for a bull was birr 623.3. On the other hand the "SDDP contact farmers" were provided with pure Friesian bulls by the SDDP for birr 300 that would be refunded to the farmers after 50 calves are born through the bull's service.

block.head: Bull management
block.p: 83.3% of the farmers at Mulo-Sululta and all of the farmers at Degem kept their bulls in a separate barn, while the remaining bull owners kept their bulls in corrals mixed with other cattle. A bull was on average supplied with 3.15 kg of crop residue, 0.75 kg of wheat bran, 1 kg of oilseed meal and 4.05 kg of hay per day. Bulls on average were allowed to graze for 5.05 hours. All the bull owners at Degem and Mulo-Sululta apply a fertility test that mainly considered the morphological soundness of the bulls.

block.head: Use pattern of bulls
block.p: The average length of duration of service was 25 months for bulls owned by "SDDP contact farmers" and 18 months for "SDDP follow" farmers. The "SDDP contact farmers" and "follow farmers" were planning to continue to use the bulls for an average of 40 months and 30 months, respectively. 50% of the farmers at Mulo-Suluta and 64.3% of the farmers at Degem had plans to replace their bulls. More than half of the "SDDP contact farmers" (54.5%) and the "SDDP follow farmers" (66.7%) didn’t have the plan to continue keeping a bull considering the business of keeping bulls unprofitable. A chi-square test showed that there was no significant variation between the study areas and the two affiliation groups concerning the plan to replace bulls (p>0.05).

60 % of the bull owners at Mulo-Sululta, that were interested in keeping bull in the future, were planning to replace the bulls by a male offspring from their own herd while 40% indicated to replace their bulls by purchasing from another farm. In the case of Degem, 66.7% of the farmers were planning to replace their bulls through government sources while the remaining 33.3% were planning to buy replacement bulls from other farms. More than half of the "SDDP contact farmers" (60%), with a plan to continue bull keeping, were planning to replace their bulls from male progeny in their own farm while the remaining farmers were planning to buy replacement bulls from government sources (20%) and other farms (20%). On the other hand, 37.5% of the "SDDP follow farmers" depended on buying from government sources while 37.5% and 25% depended on other farms and own farm offspring, respectively, to replace bulls. The variations between the study areas and the affiliation groups were not significant (p>0.05).

54.5 % of the bull owners at Mulo-Sululta and 50% of the farmers at Degem culled bulls from breeding but kept them for draught purposes while the remaining percentages in both areas sold culled bulls. There was no significant variation between the study areas and the two affiliation groups (p>0.05).

block.head: Locations of breeding bulls
block.p:
The locations of breeding bulls at all the study areas are presented in Figure 5.12. Most of the farmers (80%) at Mulo-Sululta and Degem got services from village bulls. On the other hand, more farmers used their own bulls at Mulo-Suluta (17.5%) than at Degem (5%)
while more farmers used neighboring village bulls at Degem (15%) than at Mulo-Sululta (2.5%).

mm.caption: Figure 5.13. Locations of breeding bulls in relation to dairy farms at all the study areas

block.p: In Addis Ababa, 40%, 30% and 30% of the farmers got bull service from their own bulls, village bulls and bulls of neighboring villages, respectively. In addition, all the large scale farms using bull service had their own bull . The chi-square statistics result showed that there was a significant difference (p<0.001) between the different study areas and the three farm scales in Addis Ababa (p<0.05).

Nearly all the farmers at Mulo-Sululta (92.5%), most of the farmers at Degem (84.6%) and all the farmers using bull service in Addis Ababa could get the bull service within 30 minutes of walking distance while the remaining proportion of farmers at Mulo-Sululta and Degem needed between 30 minutes and 1 hour to get the bull service. There was no significant variation between the different study areas, the affiliation groups at Selale and the farm scales in Addis Ababa (p>0.05).

block.head: Mating record keeping by bull owners
block.p:
All the bull owners at Degem but only 28.6% of the bull owners at Mulo-Sululta were keeping mating records. However, most of the records at both areas were not complete and
also inconsistent over time. There was a significant (p<0.01) difference between the study areas without a significant variation between the two affiliation groups (p>0.05).

block.head: Efficiency of Natural mating
block.p: Coverage of bull service and price per conception

An average of 36 farmers were getting bull service from one bulls per year at Selale at the time of this study compared to 30 farms during the previous year. On average of 42 cows could get bull service per bull per year. The average total number of services per bull was about 40 with a range between 18 to 61 services and on average a bull could service 3 cows per day. The price per conception of bull services ranges from 3 to 5 birr.
Some efficiency parameters of bull service

More than half (54.5%) and some (22.2%) of the bull service providers among the "SDDP contact farmers" (54.5%) and the "SDDP follow farmers", respectively, could get feed back information from dairy cow owners and hence had knowledge about the efficiency of the bull service they were providing. Table 5.39 contains
the mean and standard deviation for some efficiency parameters of bull service at Selale.

table.caption: Table 5.39. Average values efficiency parameters per bull at Selale

legend.p: N= number of observations

block.p: The bull service at Selale achieved a pregnancy rate of over 95.10% and a calving rate of 94.67%. The non-return rate was also very high and, furthermore, no cow was reported to come back for service for the fourth time.

block.head: Description of organization of the National AI Center

subblock.head: Breeding bulls owned by the Center
subblock.p: The Center owned 50 breeding bulls out of which 14 were used for semen collection while the remaining 36 bulls were replacement bulls. There were nine Holstein-Friesian (64.1%) two Barka (14.3%), two 50% Friesian and Arsi crosses (14.3%) and one 75% Friesian and Arsi cross (7.1%) bulls used in the Center for semen collection.

The average age of bulls , age at first service, length of service time and the lactation milk yield of the bulls' dam are compiled in Table 5.40. The maximum length of service of bulls at the Center was stated to be 70 months.

table.caption: Table 5.40. Age, age at first service, length of service time and lactation milk yield of bulls' dam by breed at the NAIC

legend.p: AFC= age at first service

subblock.head: Bull management
subblock.p: Bull housing and feeding: the breeding bulls of the Centre have been housed in a well constructed barn. The pure Friesian bulls and other crossbred bulls, that are big in size, are kept separately (1 bull/pen) while local bulls or replacement bulls have been kept at two per pen. The bulls are allowed to leave their pens and have some exercise for one hour every day and their hooves are examined for necessary trimming. Each bull in the Centre is supplied with hay (adlibitum), 3 kgs of a balanced concentrate and 25 gm mineral lick per day.

Bull selection: The Centre imports bulls from abroad that are progeny tested and gets also information about the milk productivity of the bulls' dam. Selection criteria are high daily
milk yield, lactation length and fat content of milk. In addition, the Centre has been also checking for functional efficiency factors like libido, temperament, body condition and morphological soundness of the bulls.

Age at first service: the most important characteristic the Centre uses to determine the readiness of bulls for service is the age of bulls coupled with evaluation of semen quality. The Centre is performing semen evaluation for bulls starting from 18 months of age.

Record keeping: even if it was not complete over the time, the Centre has been keeping records of semen evaluation analyses for each bull. The Centre has also kept monthly records of number of first, second, third and fourth services, number of pregnancies and number of progenies per inseminators. Even though the Centre has the mandate to record milk performance of AI progenies as part of the National Dairy Recording Scheme, there were no valuable information collected at the time of this study.

Bull fertility tests and culling: The Centre had no defined time table to test the fertility of breeding bulls. Casual fertility tests are performed based on reports on the field efficiency of the AI. The fertility test included palpation of the testicles for abnormalities, measuring scrotal circumference and rectal examination of the accessory glands and semen evaluation. The Centre has been culling bulls that failed the fertility tests
and sell the bulls for slaughter.
Disease control: the Centre has been performing Brucellosis test on each bull every six months and no bull was positively tested so far.

subblock.head: Semen production
subblock.p: Semen production in the Centre had no consistent trend through the years from 1995 to 1999 (Figure 5.13). 2.77%, 7.08%, 3.57%, 4.45% and 12.80% of the semen straws produced were discarded in 1995, 1996, 1997, 1998 and 1999, respectively. 30.9%, 14.8%, 12% and 9.5% of the discarded semen straws were so due to poor motility, presence of blood in the semen, high dead-alive cell ratio and poor concentration, respectively.

mm.caption: Figure 5.14. Number of semen straws produced, semen straws discarded and loss in birr in the National Artificial Insemination Centre

subblock.p: A relatively high percentage of the straws (28.7%) were also discarded due to technical failures during semen production. The remaining percentage (4.2%) was accounted for poor motility after thawing.

The Centre calculated an average production cost of 14 birr (1.75 EUR) per dose. The Centre has been charging 5 birr per conception in and around Addis Ababa and 2 birr per conception in the rural areas. When this cost is multiplied with the average national value for the number of services per conception (2.4), the Centre has incurred a cost of birr 40.8 (5 EUR) per conception. Thus, the Centre has been subjected to a loss of birr 35.8 or 38.8 per conception in and around Addis Ababa and in rural areas, respectively. Furthermore, the high number of discarded straws does also amount to a large monetary loss.

subblock.head: Semen quality
subblock.p:
The Centre has been performing semen quality evaluation tests for semen collected at the AI station taking into consideration semen volume, spermatozoa concentration per ml of semen, mass motility, individual motility and thaw motility.
