section.head: Venereal disease awareness, incidences of abortion and prevalence of Brucellosis
section.p: All the cows and bulls included in this study in all the study areas tested negatively for Brucellosis using the Rose Bengal Plate Test. The results of this study also showed that most of the farmers at Selale, 82.5% at Mulo-Sululta and 90% at Degem were not aware of any disease that is transmissible through mating. In addition, all the bull owners at Mulo-Sululta and Degem had no any idea about venereal diseases. More "SDDP contact farmers" (22.6%) were aware of venereal diseases than "SDDP follow farmers" (8.2%). In Addis Ababa, more than half of the farmers (60%) were aware of venereal diseases. Most of the large scale (71.4%) and medium scale (71.4%) dairy farms and slightly more than half of the small scale farmers (53.8%) knew of venereal diseases.

Only 2.5% of the farms at Selale, all of which were farms of "SDDP contact farmers", reported incidences of abortion. In addition, none of the bull owners at Selale area encountered cases of abortion within the dairy cows herd that got service from their bulls. In Addis Ababa, there were incidences of abortion in 37.5% of the farms. The highest incidences in Addis Ababa were in large scale farms (85.7%) followed by medium scale (42.9%) and small scale farms (23.1%). Most of the abortions occurred in farms that used both AI and bull service in Addis Ababa (66.7%) and the abortion incidence in farms that used bull service (36.7%) was higher than those that used AI (28.6%). 80% of the abortions in Addis Ababa and all the abortions at Selale area took place before the third trimester of pregnancy. The remaining 20% of the abortions in Addis Ababa took place during the third trimester of pregnancy. All farmers, with incidences of abortion in their farms, diagnosed abortion by seeing the aborted foetus. Most of the small scale farmers (80.8%) and more than half of the medium scale farmers (51.7%) did not know which bull served their cows immediately before the incidence of abortion whereas 71.4% of the large scale farms with incidences of abortion knew the bulls that served their cows. All the medium and large scale farmers and 80% of the small scale farmers with incidences of abortion kept the cows with histories of abortion in their farms till the time this study was carried out. The remaining proportion of cows with incidences of abortion in the small scale farms were sold to other farms. All the farms with incidences of abortion, irrespective of the farm scale, were using the same bull or semen from AI bulls for breeding after abortion. Only 7.7% of the small scale farms experienced abortion again.

subsection.head: Farming system characteristics at Selale
subsection.p: The mean values for family size at Selale area (7.54 persons) were closer to those reported by Abdinasir (2000) (7.9 persons per household at Arsi area) and considerably higher than those reported by Niftalem (2000) (5.6 persons and 4.6 persons at Inewari and Debre Berhan, respectively). Another result of this study indicated that cattle herd size was significantly and positively affected by family size. Similar findings were reported by Abdinasir (2000). It seems that households with larger family size are encouraged to own more livestock since they have a large family labor resource. The mean labor force required per household at Selale was estimated to be 5.5 persons (MOA and FINNIDA, 1996). Furthermore, the findings of this study indicated that most of the responsibilities for dairy cattle management were that of the husbands and wives were participating in all the activities and were primarily responsible for herding of dairy cattle. This shows that the responsibilities pertaining dairy cattle management requires the attention of family members with a higher status since crossbred dairy cattle are considered as high value assets. However, othe reports that took into consideration the whole livestock herd indicated that activities like milking and barn cleaning were restricted to women, feed preparation and feeding were the responsibilities of men and herding was taken care of by children (MOA/FINNIDA, 1996, Getachew et al., 1993).

The cattle herd compositions found in both woredas of Selale were dominated by cows (38.7-44.7%) most of which were crossbred (62-74%). This finding is partly in agreement with what has been reported by Gashaw et al. (1991) for Selale where cows comprised 51.8% of the cattle herd, 62% of which were indigenous. The high proportion of cows in the cattle herd and the increasing proportion of crossbred cows indicate the importance of dairying at Seale area.

Oxen (steers), that are mainly kept in the household for ploughing (Panin and Brokken 1993), also comprised a significant proportion of the cattle herd at Selale area (31.4%) which is in agreement with the reports of Abdinasir (2000) and Getachew et al. (1993) who indicated that a considerable proportion of the cattle herd was also composed of oxen
at Arsi area (43.23%) and Inewari (38%), respectively. The high proportion of oxen in the cattle herd is the reflection of the importance of cropping in the areas. Shapiro et al. (2000) reported that in the central highlands of Ethiopia, the income from crop sales comprises about 31% of the total farm income in households that keep crossbred dairy cows.

The results of this study showed also that crop yield per hectare at Selale had significant and positive associations with the number of crossbred cows in a farm, the amount of concentrate supplementation and the estimated daily milk yield. Estimated daily milk yield increased with the increment of concentrate supplementation and the level of exotic blood. It is assumed that this increases income to the household due to increased milk sales which in turn improves liquidity that could be used to intensify inputs to crop production. Shapiro et al. (2000) reported that about 44% of the farm income in households keeping crossbred dairy cattle in the central highlands of Ethiopia was from dairy sales. The finding in this study that estimated daily milk yield is significantly and positively affected by genotype of cows and feeding is in agreement with previous reports. According to Kiwuwa et al. (1983) indigenous breeds had a significantly lower lactation milk yield than 50% crosses of Friesian and Arsi. In addition, Abdinasir (2000) has also reported that the up-grading level of cows significantly affected milk yield, with high grade cows producing more milk than the low grade cows.
Tawah et al. (1995), at the Assela station in the Arsi region of Ethiopia, revealed that lactation performance of pure breed Arsi and crosses of Friesian and Arsi breeds was significantly and positively affected by postpartum supplementation with concentrate mixes. Improved milk yield after supplementation with concentrates was reported also by Little et al. (1987), Kurtu (1992) and Khalili et al. (1991).

subsection.head: Farming system characteristics in Addis Ababa
subsection.p:
The family size of dairy farm households in Addis Ababa (5.58 persons) is comparable with that reported by Demeke and Wolde-Gabriel (1985) who reported an average family size of 5.4 persons. In contrast to Selale area, most of the management activities in the medium and large scale farms were run by sons of the household and this could be probably due to the fact that 60.5% of the dairy cattle owners in this study had a side line occupation and could not fully handle the responsibility of dairy cattle management. On the other hand, the dairy management could also be a good professional option for sons of the households in considering the fact that alternative job opportunities are scarce. In
addition, hired labor was also being used in the large scale and medium scale farms since the owners can afford labor wages. In the small-scale farms, the involvement of the husband and the wife was considerable and comparable to that of the Selale area.

The proportion of cows with 75% or more exotic blood increased with farm size and households without sideline occupation (specializing in dairy) kept significantly larger herd size and larger number of crossbred cows with 75% or more exotic blood than those with sideline occupations. This shows that most of the large scale farmers were specializing in dairy. In addition, wheat bran supplementation was significantly and positively affected by farm size. Another result of this study revealed that daily milk yield increased with the increment of farm size, exotic blood level and concentrate supplementation (oilseed meal and wheat bran). These all indicate that specialized dairy farmers in Addis Ababa have access to external feed resources which allow the use of cows with high exotic blood levels. In turn, specialized urban dairy afrmers attain the highest milk yield of all systems included in this study.

The findings regarding effects of genotypes of cows and concentrates on estimated daily milk yield are in agreement with results of works of Kiwuwa et al (1983), Kurtu (1992), Little et al. (1987) and Khalili et al. (1991).

subsection.head: National dairy cattle breed improvement activities
subsection.p:
Ethiopia has no active breeding policy and breeding program that provides the frame and standards for breeding activities in the country. A breeding policy prepared by the Ministry of Agriculture and submitted to the government in 1985 was never put to action till to date. In addition, the Ethiopian Agricultural Research Organization has recently prepared working documents on livestock breeding policies and is awaiting further refinement through a workshop and approval from the government. The report of a study project involving a group of students of the Department of Tropical and Subtropical Animal Breeding of the Humboldt University of Berlin (2000) substantiates this fact, and highlights that there were no breeding associations or co-operatives of breeders, no identification and performance recording policy, no program for distributing bull services and no breeding program indicating breeding objectives and subsequent activities.
However, there were a number of attempts at different times by the government in collaboration with donors and non-governmental organizations to improve the productivity of dairy cattle in the country. These attempts include the Dairy Cattle Crossbreeding Program at IAR (Institute of Agricultural Research), the Chilalo Agricultural Development project, the Establishment of the National AI Center, Establishment of Dairy Cattle Improvement Ranches, the Selale Peasant Dairy Development Pilot Project and the Small-holder Dairy Development Projects. These attempts had played their own role in developing the dairy sector in the country. However, according to EARO (2001) a number of reasons have been hampering dairy cattle breed improvement activities. Some of the projects lacked a well defined breeding program and have not taken into account the existing production systems, animal health situations and feed resources. The productivity of improved breeds of cattle were thus constrained by erratic and inadequate rainfall that cause a low fodder yield potential, the need for concentrates which are not available at affordable prices and a wide variety of fatal diseases. In addition, the relatively better performing projects lacked sustainability. Zarate (1996) indicated that a long term breeding strategy can be pursued only if conditions are favorable as animal breeding requires stability and continuity.

subsection.head: Breeding practices by individual farmers
subsection.p: The results of this study showed that high daily milk yield was the most important preferred performance trait by individual farmers, irrespective of the study areas, affiliations and farm scales. It was also placed as the first priority performance trait by both the dairy cow owners and the bull owners. This indicates the importance of milk as a source of income in market oriented dairy production system in the urban, per-urban and rural highland areas. The impact of the SPDDPP and SDDP achieved through the introduction and distribution of crossbred dairy cattle and improved feed, and the improvement in the milk marketing and processing infrastructure are the main determinants for farmers to consider milk yield as the most important trait at Selale. In addition. expanded market opportunities in Addis Ababa and other regional towns and cities, act as a stimulant for development of dairy production and increased use of crossbred cows.

High fat content was also considered as a preferred performance trait by a significant proportion of farmers at Mulo-Sululta that is located closer to Addis Ababa but where the DDE milk collection centers are less developed than at Degem. Thus, the lack of a market infrastructure for liquid milk changes the emphasis on butter production to optimize the utilization of milk produced in the region. Debrah (1990) reported that those rural dairy farms located within 20 km distance from Addis Ababa and far from the milk collection centers sold less fresh milk and more butter and cheese. Previously, Gryseels and de Boudt (1986) indicated the importance of high fat content and recommended crossbreeding with breeds that produce milk with higher butter fat content in areas with poor road and market accesses where milk needs to be processed to cheese and butter.

Age at first calving was also one of the preferred performance trait mentioned by farmers in all the study areas. This could be explained by the overall mean values of age at first calving in this study that are in general high (39.4 months at Selale and 30 months in Addis Ababa). Furthermore, the average value of age at first calving at Selale was higher than that of Addis Ababa. The fact that the dairy herd in Addis Ababa is dominated by up-graded cows could be the reason for the differences. This is supported by the finding in this study that age at first calving decreased with the increment of exotic blood level across the different study areas. This finding is in agreement with the report of Negussie et al (1998) who indicated a significant effect of breed of cow on age at first calving, with F 1 cross heifers (from local cows and Jersey and Friesian sires) calving significantly earlier than indigenous heifers. Kiwuwa et al. (1983) also reported that the 75% exotic crosses with Arsi calved significantly earlier than all other breed groups.

The results of this study showed that farmers mainly depended on indirect information about performances of individual dairy cows inorder to decide on which cow to acquire. This indicates that farmers tend to relay on indirect information about cow's own performance in situations where there are no performance recording activities. The accuracy of indirect information not based on official recording of performances is difficult to access and farmers, thus, are exposed to high trabsaction costs whenever cows are purchased. At Degem, many farmers were also using the information about the dam and progeny of cows to acquire cows. This is mainly because, SPDDPP and SDDP had been doing development work at Degem for about two decades and thus there is a limited activity of performance recording by farmers. Almost all bull owners depended on the
performance information they get about the dam of the bulls. Payne and Wilson (1999) stated that progeny performance is a particularly valuable source of information to select bulls. However, Syrstad and Ruane (1998) indicated that the long time required to see progeny performance is one of the drawbacks of progeny testing and selection based on pedigree information resulted in faster rate of genetic improvement. In addition, the long generation intervals and difficulties in establishing and running a field milk-recording system are also indicated by Chacko (1994) as problems related to performance identification based on progeny.

The findings of this study showed that the introduction of crossbred cows with higher exotic blood was considered as an option by nearly half of the farmers at Selale area and slightly more than half of the farmers in Addis Ababa to improve the milk production. Another study conducted at Selale area some years before also indicated that the interviewed farmers were in favor of exotic cows and the authors predicted that their number probably would increase in the future (Gashaw et al., 1991). Azage et al. (2000) stated that crossbred and grade animals were preferred by 44% of the intra-urban dairy farmers in Addis Ababa. On the other hand, a significant portion of the farmers in this study at all the study areas were not in favor of the idea of introducing high grade dairy cows and most of the farmers in all the study areas did not have the plan to introduce purebred exotic cows, rather they stressed the importance of improving their feeding regime. This could be due to the uncertainty of farmers regarding their capability to manage cows with higher exotic blood levels. The importance of considering the available resource and ecological production conditions in planing a breed improvement program was indicated by Peters (1991). In addition, he elaborated that any increase in production intensity in association with breed improvement programs changes cost-benefit ratios and increases production risk and, thus, requires the ability of farmers to sustain this changes. Furthermore, Syrstad (1985) testified that upgrading of exotic blood over 50% does not increase milk yield. In another work, Syrstad (1998) indicated that even if crossbreeding has in most cases led to a dramatic increases in productivity in the first crossbred generation (F 1 ), but further upgrading by repeated back crossing to exotic bulls has often resulted in problems which can be ascribed to lack of adaptation. In addition, Sjoberg (1985) reported that to produce the same amount of milk the high graded cows require more concentrate feed than others.

In Addis Ababa, there was a significant difference between the farm scales concerning their preferred option to improve the productivity of their dairy cattle. Most of the large scale farmers were satisfied with the performance potential of their dairy herd while the majority of the small scale and medium scale farmers had the intention of introducing crossbred cows with higher exotic blood. This is related to the genotype composition of the dairy herd in Addis Ababa in that most of the high grade cows are owned by large scale farms while a significant proportion of the dairy herds of small scale and medium scale farms were composed of crossbred cows with 50% or less exotic blood.

Concerning options preferred by farmers to improve age at first calving and calving interval, almost of all the farmers at Mulo-Sululta believed that both traits could be improved through improved feeding regime. Their preference is proved by the reports of Dennis and Thiongane (1978) who indicated that Gobra (Senegal Fulani) heifers kept on pasture and fed balanced concentrate supplement calved at an earlier age (30 months) than unsupplemented heifers. At Degem and in Addis Ababa, a considerable proportion of the farmers had the opinion that both traits could be improved by raising the level of exotic blood in their herd. However, the work of Syrstad (1985) indicated that upgrading has negative effects on age at first calving and calving interval. Another result of this study showed that calving interval significantly decreased with increased level of education and was lowest in farms owned by civil servants in Addis Ababa, which may be related to the effect of improved management. The increased awareness of better educated farmers and civil servants through formal education and affiliations to agricultural fields for improved postpartum management and heat detection could have contributed considerably to improve management efficiency.

section.head: Bull service and AI organization and efficiency

subsection.head: General considerations
subsection.p:
About 99% of the total cattle population (about 99%) in Ethiopia is composed of indigenous cattle (AFRDMD and MOA, 1991). There are over six main cattle types in Ethiopia which have a regional distribution and have evolved under the impact factors like climate, altitude, available feed supply, endemic diseases, preferred function and management circumstances (Albero and Solomon (1982) and Ethiopian Mapping Agency, (1981)). These indigenous cattle are handled by smallholder farmers and are kept mainly
as part of the mixed crop-livestock production systems and the pastoral production systems (MOA, 1993). Mating is often random and there is no strict selection of mating pairs (Bittner et al., 2000). The remaining small proportion of cattle population in Ethiopia is composed of improved genotypes (purebred exotic or crossbred cattle) and kept by large scale state and private owned dairy farms, intra-urban and peri-urban small-holder dairy farms and market-oriented rural-small-holder mixed crop-livestock farms in the central highlands. Crossbreeding of indigenous cows with exotic bulls either through natural mating or AI, is practiced to attain an improved production level. However, to date there is no breeding policy and formal organization and coordination of the bull service or the AI service at either national or regional level in a way to optimize crossbreeding and mating services. In order to acquire crossbred cows farmers have to organize their own access to breeding bulls, unless they are part of projects like the SDDP which provide and organize breeding services.

Most of the farmers at Selale were using natural mating with crossbred bulls kept by individual farmers while most of the farmers in and around Addis Ababa were using AI. The farmers at Selale were getting the bull service without any major problem and had no difficulty in bringing a cow in heat to a bull service farm. The results also indicated that a significant proportion of SDDP follow farmers were not familiar with the AI service. These results showed that natural service is the best practical option for farmers at Selale. Similar findings were reported by Abdinasir (2000) who found AI being used by the majority of the farmers (87.5%) at Bilalo located relatively closer to Asela, where there is a well developed infrastructure for AI services, whereas it was only used by a very small proportion of the farmers at Lemmu (8.3%) located relatively far from Asela. These all indicate that AI seemed to be constrained by a number of factors to extend services to the rural areas while it has been effective in Addis Ababa even if there was still the problem of punctuality in delivering the service. A number of reasons like organizational problems associated with the administration of the AI service, lack of logistical support related to production and distribution of semen and liquid nitrogen supply, lack of well trained and experienced AI technicians, communication problems between AI technicians stationed usually in Woreda towns and farmers living far from main roads, and communication technologies all contribute to the poor effectiveness of the AI service at Selale area.
Azage et al. (1995) and a summary of a recent FAO electronic conference (2000) on the appropriateness, significance and application of individual biotechnologies in developing
countries indicated that poor heat detection skills of farmers, poor semen quality, inappropriate semen handling procedures, wrong timing of insemination and inefficiency of inseminators, insufficient means of communication and infrastructure, difficulty to bear costs for the production of liquid nitrogen and purchase of necessary equipment and poor management of AI operations are some of the problems associate with AI.

subsection.head: Bull service organization at village level
subsection.p: SDDP had been the most important source of breeding bulls at Seale area. The project provided purebred Friesian bulls, to individual farmers for birr 300 which had to be given back to the farmers after 50 calves had been born through the bull's service (SDDP/OAB, 1999). The results of this study showed that 36 farms or 42 cows are attended per bull in the course of a year. Even though the average number of farms attended per bull was below what had been intended by the SDDP (78 farms per bull), the average number of cows attended per bull was close to previous bull-cow ratio recommendations. Barrett and Larkin (1974) recommended a bull-cow ratio of 1:50-60 for hand mating where mating is done at owners discretion. Lee et al. (1998) recommended a bull-cow ratio of 1: 40-50.

On average, the "SDDP contact farmers" and the "SDDP follow farmers" planned to use their breeding bulls for a total period of four to five years and more than half of the bull owners did not have the plan to replace their bulls. The lack of confidence by farmers at Selale to acquire a replacement bull indicates some serious organizational problems in liking rural farmers with sources of good breeding stock; a task previously performed by SDDP, that phased out at the time of this study. Lee et al. (1998) and IIRR (2000) recommended to use a bull from 2 to 4 years in a herd and replace or switch it thereafter. By taking a bull-cow ratio of 1:42, which is working well at Selale area, it is possible to project that about 880 breeding bulls are required per year to serve about 37000 crossbred cows found within the central highlands of the country. If the bulls are used for four years and with a risk allowance of 10 % due to diseases, fertility problems and mortality, a total of 242 replacement bulls need to be available annually.

The bull service at Selale provided efficient service to users and resulted in a high non-return rate, pregnancy rate and calving rate. High efficiency rates due to bull service was also reported by previous works. Wattiaux (1998) stated that many farmers believe that pregnancy rates are higher when a bull is used, even in areas where artificial insemination
has proven to be very effective. In addition, Naidoo et al (1981) reported in Mauritius that natural mating was more effective than AI with 91% of calving intervals being less than 14 months compared with only 49 % from AI. The work of Hailemariam et al. (1983) also indicated that calving interval of Boran cows served by Boran bulls were shorter than those of cows served by AI.

No cow or breeding bull was tested positive for Brucellosis in this study and the farm incidence of abortion was very low and these encourage the use of bull services in the rural areas. Very low prevalence rates of Brucellosis were reported in the rural areas by Tekleye et al. (1989), Abebe (1989) and Bayleyegn (1989). However, farmers at Selale in general were not aware of venereal diseases and this indicates a lack of extension work to increase farmers awareness on venereal diseases, especially with the introduction of crossbred cows and bull services in the area.

subsection.head: AI service organization and delivery
subsection.p: The irregular trend of semen production in the National Artificial Insemination Center over the years from 1995 to 1999 could indicate inconsistency in the activities of the Center. Either the Center had no clear objectives and production plans or there were irregularities in the allocation of funds and other inputs to the Center, making it difficult for the Center to fulfil its objectives. The Center also had to discarded significant portions of the semen produced. It was not clear why the Center was processing semen with poor mass or individual motility and concentration, with a high dead-alive ratio and with blood contamination. It would have been better if semen with either of the above mentioned problems was discarded at the time of collection before any additional processing and storage cost had been incurred. In addition, the cost-price ratio for semen straws showed that the AI service is highly subsidized. However, farmers in the rural areas were not beneficiaries of this subsidy since the service is not readily available while urban and peri-urban farmers, that are in a better financial status and could pay more, are benefiting most from this subsidy.

The average values of semen volume (6.82-9.35 ml), spermatozoa concentration (1.14-1.39 X 10 9 / ml), mass motility (68.2-75.5%) and thaw motility (44-51%) found in this study are not much different from reports of previous works. The National AI Center previously produced semen of Friesian bulls with a volume of 6.7 to 9.6 ml while spermatozoa
concentration ranges in value from 1.1 to 1.4 X 10 9 / ml and mass motility and thaw motility varied from 76.5-79% and 51.4-51.2% respectively (Azage et al., 1995). The semen quality values of this study are greater than those reported by Stolla and Trombach (1999) in Germany. They reported that in 1996 the mean semen volume for AI bull stations using Simmental, Holstein-Friesian and Brown Swiss breeds ranges from 4.05 ml to 5.2 ml and spermatozoa concentration of the bulls ranged from 0.944 X 10 9 to 1.245 X 10 9 .

The semen quality at the National AI Center was significantly affected by year of production, season of the year and breed of bulls. There was a tendency of an increased semen volume and decreased thaw motility in recent years. The other traits varied irregularly over the years. Regarding seasonal differences, all the semen traits except thaw motility were higher in the wet season. In addition, 75 % Friesian-Arsi crosses had the best volume, 50% Friesian-Arsi crosses had the highest concentration, Jersey bulls had the best motility and Friesian bulls had the best thaw motility. The variation of semen quality traits through time is also reported by van Os et al. (1997) and Foote (1978). The work of Mathelon et al. (1998) indicated that season significantly affected all semen traits in young bulls but did not significantly affect semen volume and spermatozoa concentration in mature bulls. They reported that semen traits were better in winter than in summer. In addition, Kumi-Diaka et al. (1981) reported that higher sperm abnormalities, lower percentage of live spermatozoa and lower sperm concentrations were observed in Bos taurus bulls in the tropics during hot periods. However, this difference was not observed in Bos indicus bulls.
Azage et al. (1995) indicated that season alters endocrine profiles and hence influences fertility. He further elaborated that hyperthermia reduces testosterone levels and impairs the maintenance of normal spermatogenesis. A significant breed effect on semen traits was reported by Chenoweth et al. (1996) with temperate Bos taurus (Angus and Hereford) breeds being generally superior to Bos indicus breeds (Brahman, Nellore X Brahman) in sperm motility and percentages of normal spermatozoa. On the other hand, Tegene et al. (1992) reported that there was no significant variation between young pubertal Boran and crossbred Boran-Friesian bulls in semen traits. The better performance of the crossbreeds in this study with respect to semen traits could be due to their ability to withstand environmental stresses better than the purebred exotic bulls.

The AI application in Addis Ababa varied from 8756 to 9138 cases per year between 1997/98 and 1999/00. According to the information released from the Center (2000) the average annual AI applications per year for the years from 1984 to 2000 were 20649. This indicates that 42.2% to 44.3% of the AI activity took place in Addis Ababa. The average annual AI application by the National Artificial Insemination Center in the country was lower than the average value that has been reported by Chupin and Schuh (1992) for African countries. Their report indicated that the average AI applications per year per country in Africa is 30637 which is far below the values for Asian, Latin America and Near East countries.

The
average values of non-return rates (60-90 days) for the National AI Center were higher than those reported by Rocha et al. (2001) for one of the largest dairy cooperatives in Portugal (71.7%) and by Leichniak et al. (1998) for dairy bulls in Poland (60%, 60 days). Mukassa-Mugrewa et al (1991) reported that pregnancy rates to AI do not exceed 45% in Africa. The exceptionally high non-return rate value in the National AI Center of Ethiopia could arise from the poor quality of post AI service recording. Another reason could also be that AI might have been compounded with subsequent natural service. Many farmers use bull services in times of AI failure, without reporting this to inseminators. The fact that the non-return rate was significantly affected only by the inseminators in this study could also indicate the possibility that AI failure could be linked to the skills of inseminators. This finding is in agreement with what has been reported by Rocha et al. (2001) and Vandoormaal (1993). Wittiaux (1998) indicated that improper insemination technique is one of the problems associated with low efficiency of AI.

The regular test practice for Brucellosis on the bulls owned by the National Artificial Insemination Center and the absence of positively tested bulls is encouraging. The result of this study showed that there was no positively tested dairy cow for Brucellosis in Addis Ababa where most of the farmers are using AI. However, this finding is not in agreement with that of Yilkal (1998). He reported a total prevalence rate of 8.1% (using the Rose Bengal Plate Test and Complement Fixation Test) for crossbred cows in intra- and peri-urban dairy production systems in and around Addis Ababa. There are reports indicating that Brucellosis is rarely transmitted through mating (Sprott and Field, 1998). However, if semen from infected bull is used for AI, there is a considerable risk of inseminated cows being infected. The most important risk factors for the transmission of Brucellosis are poor
hygienic conditions like exposure to aborted foetus, placentas or new born calves from infected cows (Thumond and Hietala, 2000) and hence it is more important in larger herds than smaller herds. This fact was witnessed by Yilkal (1998) in that the prevalence of Brucellosis was significantly higher in herds that kept more than 100 cattle (9.1%) than those that kept less than or equal to 50 cattle (3.3%). The absence of positive reactors for Brucellosis test in this study could be due to the small herd size of most of the farms in Addis Ababa included in the sampling. Only seven farms with a herd size of more than 10 cows were included in this study. In addition, the recent work of Yilkal (1998) in Addis Ababa could have contributed a lot in increasing the awareness of farmers in and around Addis Ababa and measures could have been taken by farmers to eliminate positive cows. This is evidenced by another finding of this study that showed most farmers were aware of the risk of venereal diseases in Addis Ababa. The value on awareness in this study is much higher than the report of Yilkal (1998) who found that 87.8% of the farms in and around Addis Ababa were not aware of venereal diseases. However, the proportion of farms which experienced abortion in Addis Ababa was high and is not much different from that reported by Yilkal (1998). He reported that 56.1% of the farms experienced abortions in and around Addis Ababa. In addition, this study showed that the proportion of farms which experienced abortion was increasing with the increment of farm size in Addis Ababa. This situation was also observed by Tekleye et al (1989) in the Central Ethiopia. In their work, the highest incidence rate of abortion was found in the largest farm. Increase in herd size could expose cows to more physical stress, insufficient observation and management, competition for available feed resource and infections. This study showed also that the highest propotion of farms which experienced abortion were farmers that used both bull service and AI service. One of the reasons for the high incidence rate of abortion in farms using both AI and bull service could be repeated services without proper pregnancy diagnosis. Dailey (1992) indicated that insemination of pregnant cows leads to abortions.

chapter.head: Conclusions and recommendations
chapter.p: At Selale and in small scale farms in Addis Ababa, family members are the most important sources of labor. In addition, responsibilities of dairy cattle management were undertaken mostly by members of the family at high status, husband and wife. Dairying is also an important source of income to the household in both areas. These indicate that dairying is becoming an important component of the farming activities at Selale and a means of livelihood and a part-time business for most of the smallholders in Addis Ababa.

Crop yield per hectare was positively associated with the number of crossbred dairy cows, the daily milk output and concentrate input, and this is a reflection of intensification of crop production enabled by market oriented dairy in the rural area. It is important, therefore, to improve market linkages to the rural areas.
In Addis Ababa, inputs in terms of genotypes of dairy cows and feed, and milk output were higher in specialized dairy farms than in farms owned by part-time farmers.
A future dairy development plan in the urban area needs to give appropriate attention to this distinction between the types of farmers in the urban and peri-urban dairy production systems.
In the absence of formal performance information farmers relay on informal individual cow performance observation for purchase of cows and selection of replacements. This indicates that t
here is a need for a community based action to develop alternative reliable performance assessment and documentation options.

The preferred performance traits in the different study areas reflected their relative economic value in their respective localities. Milk yield performance was preferred in all locations while high fat content was also considered in locations with low market linkage.
Therefore, economically based breeding objectives need to be defined in the context of the existing production conditions and market relations in the areas.

Natural mating is the essential mating practice in rural areas with easily accessibility and a satisfactory efficiency as a result of SDDP intervention. However, the continuity of the bull service is at stake due to the absence of an efficient bull replacement scheme.
This indicates the importance for defining a breeding program to secure the ability for selecting replacement bulls in a sustainable way.
AI is most prominent in urban and peri-urban dairy production systems but with variable reliability in terms of timely service.

To make AI more reliable delivery modes need to be improved. In addition, the AI service highly subsidizes the urban and per-urban farmers (the actual AI users) which are capable of paying more. It is thus essential to undertake cost-price analyses to come up with a reasonable price.

The fact that no cow and bull was found positive for Brucellosis in all the study areas indicates that currently there is no risk in using bull service. However, it is important to undertake regular tests for Brucellosis on breeding bulls (natural and AI) to monitor future risks of infection.

chapter.head: Summary
chapter.p: This study was carried out at Selale area and in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. The main objectives were to understand the conditions of dairy production systems and identify the existing breeding practices and organizational patterns and efficiency of bull services and artificial insemination with some hygienic considerations.

A sample of 80 households (31 "SDDP contact farmers" and 49 "SDDP follow farmers") that owned 236 dairy cows and 20 households (10 "SDDP contact farmers" and 10 "SDDP follow farmers") that own 20 breeding bulls were selected randomly from the Selale area (Mulo-Sululta and Degem) and a sample of 40 dairy farms (26 small scale, 7 medium scale and 7 large scale) that owned 491 dairy cows were selected randomly from Addis Ababa. A detail questionnaire was prepared and data were collected based on one visit interview that was supported with observation. In addition, personal communication with the National Artificial Insemination Center personnel and data collected by the Center for five years (1995-1999) were being used as sources of data. All the dairy cows and breeding bulls included in this study were also tested for Brucellosis using the Rose Bengal Plate Test. Data collected from the dairy cow and bull owners include farming system and socioeconomic characteristics, dairy cattle feeding, estimated performance of dairy cattle, sources of information for acquisition of dairy cows and breeding bulls, preferred performance traits by farmers, options set by farmers to improve dairy performance, bull service organization and efficiency, AI service organization and efficiency and awareness of farmers on venereal diseases prevalence and control methods. The data were analyzed using the SPSS computer software (SPSS for windows, release 10.05, 1999). Bar graphs were prepared using the Microsoft Excel (2000) program while line graphs were prepared using the Statistica computer software (Statistica for widows, Kernel release 5.5 A, 1999).

The overall mean for family size in all the study areas was 6.9 persons. The highest mean value for family size was found at Degem with 8.10 persons and the lowest mean value for family size was found in Addis Ababa with 5.58 persons. There was no much difference between Mulo-Sululta (9.73 TLU) and Degem (9.20 TLU) in livestock holding. In both areas, the livestock herd was dominated by cattle (54.8%) and sheep (32.7%). With regard to cattle herd size and composition, cows contribute the highest proportion in all the study
areas. Cows comprised 38.3% and 44.7% of the cattle herd at Mulo-Sululta and Degem, respectively. In Addis Ababa, more than half of the cattle herd was composed of cows.

Most of the DM supplied originated from natural pasture hay (43.7%) and crop residues (40.4%) at Selale area and 62% and 38% of the DM originated from natural pasture hay and concentrates, respectively, in Addis Ababa. Dairy cows at Selale area and in Addis Ababa were supplied with metabolizable energy that meets nearly all the maintenance and production requirement (considering the average daily milk yield in this study) and crude protein that exceeds the requirements.

At Mulo-Sululta and Degem and in small scale farms in Addis Ababa most of the responsibilities in dairy cattle management was that of the husband and wife. In all of the large scale and medium scale farms and 60% of the small scale farms in Addis Ababa feeding of the dairy cattle was done by laborers. Milking of the dairy cows and most of the management practices like breeding, health monitoring and housing were covered by sons of the farmers in medium and large scale dairy farms.

Cattle herd size was affected positively and significantly by
family size and grazing land size. Crop yield per hectare affected significantly the number of crossbred dairy cows and there was a tendency of increment in the number of crossbred dairy cows with the increment of crop yield per hectare.

In Addis Ababa, only type of side line occupation affected cattle herd size, number of cows and number of 75% crossbred cows in a herd. Households that specialize in dairy (without sideline occupation) had the largest herd size, number of cows and number of all levels of crossbred cows. Civil servants had the smallest herd size value.

In the analyses of factors affecting feeding regime, "SDDP contact farmers" supplemented significantly higher amount of concentrate than "SDDP follow farmers". In addition, supplementation with concentrates significantly increased with increment of crop yield per hectare. In Addis Ababa, supplementation with wheat bran significantly increased with the increment of the farm size.

At Selale, dairy cows owned by "SDDP contact farmers" produced significantly higher estimated daily milk yield at the middle of lactation and were milked for shorter period of time than those owned by "SDDP follow farmers". In addition, estimated daily milk yield
increased significantly with the increment of crop yield per hectare at the beginning and middle of lactation. Estimated daily milk yield increased also with the increment of percentage of exotic blood and supplementation with concentrates and crop residues at all stages of lactation.

In Addis Ababa, estimated daily milk yield increased significantly at all stages of lactation with farm size and with the increment of exotic blood and supplementation with oilseed meal. There was also a significant increment in estimated daily milk yield at the middle and end of lactation with the increment of wheat bran supplementation. In addition, dairy cows owned by farmers with out sideline occupation gave significantly higher estimated daily milk yield at the beginning of lactation while those dairy cows owned by civil servants gave significantly higher daily milk yield in the middle and at the end of lactation. As to the lactation length, farmers with out sideline occupation milked their cows for a significantly longer time than the others while civil servants milked their cows for a shorter time than the others.

Analyses of factors affecting the estimated reproductive performance of dairy cows at Selale area indicated that age at first calving decreased significantly as the percentage of exotic blood increased. In Addis Ababa, age at first calving increased significantly with the increment of farm size while calving interval decreased significantly with the increment of level of education. Dairy cows owned by civil servants had the shortest calving interval. Furthermore, number of services per-conception increased significantly with the increment of oilseed meal supplementation.

The most important preferred performance trait by dairy cow owners in all the study areas and the bull owners at Selale area was high daily milk yield that was considered as the first priority selection criteria in all the study areas by most of the farmers. There was a significant difference between the study areas with regard to second priority preferred performance trait, in that a considerable proportion of the farmers mentioned high fat (39.5%) and longer lactation length (31.6%) at Mulo-Sululta, shorter age at first calving (54.5%) at Degem and longer lactation length (40%) in Addis Ababa. In addition, about half of the bull owners at Mulo-Sululta and Degem put high fat content as the second priority preferred performance trait .

With regard to sources of information for acquisition of dairy cows, most of the farmers at Mulo-Sululta (95%), Degem (82.5%) and Addis Ababa (75%) individual performance information. In the case of bulls, 84.7% of the bull owners at Mulo-Sululta and all the bull owners at Degem used dam performance.

52.5-65% of the farmers in all the study areas planned to attain higher milk yield through the introduction of cross breeds with higher exotic blood into their herd. In Addis Ababa, most of the large scale farms (85.7%) were satisfied with productivity of their dairy herd while most of the small scale (76.9%) and medium scale (85.7%) farms had the plan to introduce dairy cows with higher exotic blood. Almost all the farmers at Mulo-Sululta believed that age at first calving and calving interval could be improved only with better nutrition. However, most of the farmers at Degem (77.8%) and in Addis Ababa (85.7%) planned to improve age at first calving of their dairy cattle herd through the introduction of high grade cows into their farms. With regard to calving interval, 42.5% and 57.5% of the farmers at Degem and in Addis Ababa respectively believed that calving interval could be improved through improved nutrition.

Most of the farmers both at Mulo-Sululta (90%) and Degem (85%) were using only natural mating. In Addis Ababa, 75% of the farmers used only AI. The variations between the study areas were significant. Most of the farmers at Selale area (80%) used village bulls while 40% of the farmers in Addis Ababa, most of which are large scale farms, had their own bulls. 84.6%-92.5% of the farmers at Selale area and all the farmers using bull service in Addis Ababa could get the service in less than 30 minutes of walking distance. Almost all the farmers at Selale area and in Addis Ababa using bull service were satisfied with the bull service while half of the farmers using AI in Addis Ababa were satisfied with AI. Lack of punctuality was mentioned by most of the AI users in Addis Ababa, that had problem with AI, as the most frequent problem.

The "SDDP contact farmers" were provided with bulls from the project for 300 birr (refundable after 50 calves are born) while the "SDDP follow farmers" bought bulls from individuals in the area (average price 623.3 birr). The bulls were used on average for 18-25 months and 50-64.5 % of the bull owners had plan to replace the bulls after 30-40 months. On average 36 farms and 42 cows were getting bull service per bull at Selale area and a bull could service on average 3.0 cows per day. The price per conception of bull service
ranges from 3 to 5 birr. The non-return rate (60-90 days), pregnancy rate and calving rate were 85.62- 97.31%, 95.10% and 94.67%, respectively.

The National Artificial Insemination Center owned 50 breeding bulls out of which 14 were used for semen collection and others were replacement bulls. 64.1% of the bulls used for semen collection were Friesian. The others were Barka (14.3%) and crosses between Arsi and Friesian (21.4%). The annual semen production in the Center for the years 1995-1999 ranges from 23,580 to 103,440 straws. From 2.77% to 12.8% of the semen straws were discarded per year due to a number of reasons. The Center expended 14 birr (1.75 EUR) per semen straw and charged 5 birr per conception in the urban areas and 2 birr per conception in the rural areas. The average values for semen volume, spermatozoa concentration, motility and thaw motility for the years 1995-1999 ranged from 6.82-9.35 ml, 1.14-1.39x10 9 , 68.2-75.5% and 44-51%, respectively. The non-return rate (60-90 days) in using AI ranged from 78-80%. Semen quality was significantly affected by year of production and breed of bulls while Non-return rate was affected significantly with the efficiency of inseminators.

82.5-95% of the farmers at Selale area were not aware of any disease that is transmissible though mating. In Addis Ababa, more than half of the farmers (60%) were aware of venereal diseases. The farm abortion incidence rate was 2.5% at Selale area and 37.5% in Addis Ababa. The highest incidences in Addis Ababa were in large scale farms (85.7%) followed by the medium (42.9%) and small scale farms (23.1%). With respect of prevalence of Brucellosis, all the cows and bulls tested negatively using the Rose-Bengal Plate Test.

chapter.head: Zusammenfassung
chapter.p: Die Untersuchung wurde im Gebiet Selale und in Addis Abeba, Äethiopien, durchgeführt. Die Hauptziele der Arbeit waren die Analyse der Bedingungen von Milchvieh-Produktionssystemen, Zucht- und Anpaarungspraktiken und der Organisation des Bullenservice sowie der künstlichen Besamung inkl. einiger hygienischer Betrachtungen.

Eine Stichprobe von 80 Haushalten (31 SDDP-Kontakt-Betriebe und 49 SDDP-Folge-Betriebe) mit 236 Kühen und 20 Haushalten (10 SDDP-Kontakt-Betriebe und 10 SDDP-Folge-Betriebe) mit 20 Zuchtbullen wurde zufällig aus dem Selale Gebiet (Mulo-Sululta und Degem) ausgewählt sowie eine Stichprobe von 40 Milchviehbetrieben (26 Kleinbetriebe, 7 mittelgroße Betriebe und 7 Großbetriebe) mit 491 Kühen aus Addis Abeba. Die im Landwirtschaftsministerium des Woreda Distrikts vorliegenden Haushaltslisten wurden als Grundlage für die Zufallsstichprobe verwendet. Ein detaillierter Fragebogen wurde vorbereitet, und die Daten wurden auf der Basis eines Interviews und entsprechenden Beobachtungen während eines einmaligen Betriebsbesuchs erhoben. Außerdem wurden persönliche Mitteilungen sowie Besamungsdaten von 5 Jahren (1995-1999) des National Artificial Insemination Center als Datenquellen verwendet. Sämtliche in dieser Arbeit berücksichtigten Milchkühe und Zuchtbullen wurden auf Brucellose mit dem Rose-Bengal-Ringtest untersucht. Die von den Milchkuh- und Bullenbesitzern erhobenen Daten umfassen Betriebssystem, sozio-ökonomische Charakteristika, Milchkuhfütterung, Produktivität der Milchkühe, Informationsquellen für Leistungsidentifikation, von den Bauern aufgestellte bevorzugtes Leistungsmerkmal, von den Bauern aufgestellte Optionen zur Verbesserung der Produktivität der Milchkühe, Organisation und Effizienz des Bullenservice, Organisation und Effizienz des Besamungsservice sowie Bewusstsein der Bauern über die Prävalenz von Geschlechtskrankheiten und Behandlungsmethoden. Die Daten wurden mit dem Softwareprogramm SPSS (SPSS für Windows vom 10.05.1999) analysiert. Balkendiagramme wurden mit Microsoft Excel (2000) erstellt, Liniendiagramme mit Statistica (Statistica 5.5 A, 1999).

Der Gesamtmittelwert für die Familiengröße in allen Untersuchungsgebieten lag bei 6,9 Personen. Der höchste Mittelwert für Familiengröße wurde in Degem mit 8,10 Personen gefunden, der niedrigste Mittelwert in Addis Abeba mit 5,58 Personen. Bei den
Viehbeständen gab es kaum einen Unterschied zwischen Mulo-Sululta (9,73 TLU) und Degem (9,20 TLU). In beiden Gebieten bestand die Viehherde zum größten Teil aus Rindern (54,8%) und Schafen (32,7%). Was die Rinderherde betrifft, so nahmen die Kühe den größten Anteil in allen Untersuchungsgebieten ein. Kühe umfassten 27,2% der Rinderherde in Mulo-Sululta und 35% in Degem. In Addis Abeba bestand die Rinderherde zu über der Hälfte aus Kühen.

Der größte Teil der verabreichten Trockenmasse stammte im Gebiet Selale von Heu (43,7%) und Ernterückständen (40,4%), in Addis Abeba von Heu (62%) und Kraftfutter (38%). Die Milchkühe im Gebiet Selale und in Addis Abeba wurden mit umsetzbarer Energie versorgt, die nahezu den gesamten Haltungs- und Produktionsbedarf (durchschnittliche tägliche Milchmenge in dieser Arbeit) deckten, und mit Rohprotein über den Bedarf hinaus.

In Mulo-Suluta, Degem und in den kleinen Milchviehbetrieben in Addis Ababa war der Ehemann und die Ehefrau für den größten Teil der Aktivitäten in der Rinderhaltung verantwortlich. In den großen und mittleren Betrieben sowie in 60% der Kleinbetriebe in Addis Abeba wurden Lohnarbeiter zur Fütterung der Milchkühe eingesetzt. Das Melken der Kühe und die meisten Haltungspraktiken wie Anpaarung, Überprüfung des Gesundheitszustandes und Stallung wurde in den großen und mittleren Betrieben von den Söhnen der Bauern übernommen.

Die Rinderherdengröße wurde positiv und signifikant von der Familiengröße und Weidefläche beeinflusst. Der Ernteertrag pro Hektar hatte einen signifkanten Einfluss auf die Anzahl der Kreuzungskühe mit der Tendenz einer Zunahme der Kreuzungskühe bei zunehmendem Ernteertrag pro Hektar.

In Addis Abeba hatte ausschließlich die Art des Nebenerwerbs einen Effekt auf die Herdengröße, die Anzahl Kühe und die Anzahl der 75%-Kreuzungskühe in einer Herde. Haushalte ohne Nebenerwerbstätigkeit hatten die größten Herden, die höchste Anzahl an Kühen und Kreuzungskühen aller Kreuzungsstufen. Verwaltungsbeamte hatten die kleinsten Herden.

In den Analysen der Faktoren des Fütterungsregimes, SDDP-Kontakt-Bauern fütterten mehr Kraftfutter als SDDP-Folge-Bauern. Zudem stieg die Zufütterung mit Kraftfutter mit
zunehmendem Ernteertrag pro Hektar. In Addis Abeba wurde nur die Zufütterung mit Weizenkleie signifikant von der Betriebsgröße beeinflusst, wobei die Zufütterung mit Weizenkleie mit zunehmender Betriebsgröße stieg.

Die Analyse der Faktoren der täglichen Milchmenge und der Laktationsdauer im Gebiet Selale zeigten an, dass die Milchmenge von Kühen der SDDP-Kontakt-Bauern in der Laktationsmitte signifikant höher war als die von Kühen der SDDP-Folge-Bauern und über einen deutlich kürzeren Zeitraum gemolken wurden. Die tägliche Milchmenge wurde auch noch vom Ernteertrag am Beginn und in der Mitte der Laktation signifikant beeinflusst. Auch nahm die tägliche Milchmenge mit zunehmendem exotischen Genanteil und der Zufütterung mit Kraftfutter und Ernterückständen in allen Laktationsstadien zu.

In Addis Abeba nahm die tägliche Milchmenge in allen Laktationsstadien signifikant mit der Betriebsgröße und mit zunehmendem exotischen Genanteil und der Zufütterung mit Ölsaatenmehl zu. Ebenso konnte eine signifikante Erhöhung in der Milchmenge in der Mitte und am Ende der Laktation mit zunehmender Verfütterung von Weizenkleie beobachtet werden. Außerdem gaben die Kühe von Bauern ohne Nebenerwerbstätigkeit zu Beginn der Laktation deutlich mehr Milch, während die Kühe von Verwaltungsbeamten in der Mitte und am Ende der Laktation deutlich mehr Milch gaben. Was die Laktationslänge betrifft, so wurden die Kühe von Bauern ohne Nebenerwerb deutlich länger gemolken als alle anderen, während die Kühe von Verwaltungsbeamten über den kürzesten Zeitraum hinweg gemolken wurden.

Die Analyse der Faktoren der Reproduktionsleistung der Milchkühe im Gebiet Selale zeigte, dass das Erstkalbealter signifikant mit dem exotischen Genanteil sank. In Addis Ababa nahm das Erstkalbealter signifikant mit der Betriebsgröße zu. Die Zwischenkalbezeit nahm mit zunehmendem Bildungsniveau der Bauern ab. Die Kühe von Verwaltungsbeamten häufiger kalbten als die von Haushalten mit kleinen bzw. ohne Nebenerwerbstätigkeiten. Weiterhin nahm die Zahl der Bedeckungen bzw. Besamungen mit zunehmender Zufütterung mit Ölsaatenmehl zu.

Was die Informationsquellen zur Leistungsidentifikation betrifft, so nutzten die meisten Bauern in Mulo-Sululta (95%), Degem (82,5%) und Addis Abeba (75%) die Eigenleistung der Kühe. Bei den Bullen verwendeten 84,7% der Bullenbesitzer in Mulo-Sululta und
sämtliche Bullenbesitzer in Degem die Mutterleistung als Informationsquelle zur Leistungsidentifikation.

Das für die Milchkuhbesitzern wichtigste Lesitungsmerkmal war eine hohe Milchmange, und zwar in allen Untersuchungsgebieten. Dies wurde von dem meisten Bauern in allen Untersuchungsgebieten bevorzugtes Leistungsmerkmal erster Priorität betrachtet.

Es gab einen signifikanten Unterschied zwischen den Untersuchungsgebieten hinsichtlich der bevorzugten Leistungsmerkmale zweiter Priorität: ein beträchtlicher Teil der Bauern erwähnte einen hohen Fettgehalt (39,5%) und eine längere Laktationsdauer (31,6%) in Mulo-Sululta, ein niedrigeres Erstkalbealter (54,5%) in Degem und eine längere Laktationsdauer (40%) in Addis Abeba. Außerdem nannten ungefähr die Hälfte der Bullenbesitzer in Mulo-Sululta und Degem einen hohen Fettgehalt als bevorzugtes Leistungsmerkmale zweiter Priorität.

52,5-65% der Bauern in allen Untersuchungsgebieten hatten die Absicht, einen höheren Milchertrag durch die Haltung von Kreuzungskühen mit einem höheren exotischen Genanteil zu erlangen. In Addis Abeba waren die meisten Großbetriebe (85,7%) mit der Produktivität ihrer Milchkuhherde zufrieden, die meisten kleinen (76,9%) und mittelgroßen Betriebe (85,7%) hingegen hatten die Absicht, Kreuzungskühe mit einem höheren exotischen Genanteil einzustallen (p<0,01). Jedoch hatten die meisten Bauern in Degem (77,8%) und in Addis Abeba (85,7%) vor, das Erstkalbealter ihrer Milchkuhherde durch die Einführung von Kühen mit einem hohen exotischen Genanteil zu verbessern. Was die Zwischenkalbezeit betrifft, so glaubten 42,5% der Bauern in Degem und 57,5% der Bauern in Addis Abeba, dass diese durch eine verbesserte Ernährung verbessert werden könnte.

Es gab einen signifikanten Unterschied (p<0,001) zwischen den Untersuchungsgebieten hinsichtlich der Präferenz von Methoden, die selektierten Gene zu verbreiten. Die meisten Bauern in Mulo-Suluta (90%) und in Degem (85%) machten nur vom Natursprung Gebrauch. In Addis Abeba, nutzten 75% der Bauen ausschließlich die künstliche Besamung. Die meisten Bauern im Gebiet Selale (80%) nutzten die Dorfbullen, während 40% der Bauern in Addis Abeba, die meisten davon Großbetriebe, ihren eigenen Bullen hielten. Für 84,6%-92,5% der Bauern im Gebiet Selale und alle Bauern in Addis Abeba, die den Natursprung nutzten, waren der Deckbulle in weniger als 30 Minuten Fußweg zu
erreichen. Nahezu alle Bauern im Gebiet Selale und in Addis Abeba, die den Natursprung nutzten, waren mit dem Deckservice zufrieden, während die Hälfte der Bauern in Addis Abeba, die die künstliche Besamung nutzten, mit derselben zufrieden waren. Unpünktlichkeit wurde von den meisten Nutzern der künstlichen Besamung in Addis Abeba, die Probleme damit hatten, als häufigstes Problem genannt.

Die SDDP-Kontakt-Bauern erhielten ihre Bullen vom Projekt gegen eine Bezahlung von 300 Birr (Rückerstattung nach 50 geborenen Kälbern) während die SDDP-Folge-Bauern ihre Bullen von Privatpersonen in der Gegend kauften (Durchschnittspreis 623,3 Birr). Die Bullen wurden bis dahin im Durchschnitt 18-25 Monate genutzt, und 50-64,5% der Bullenbesitzer hatten vor, die Bullen nach 30-40 Monaten zu ersetzen.

Im Durchschnitt nahmen 36 Betriebe und 42 Kühe im Gebiet Selale den Deckservice je Bulle in Anspruch, und ein Bulle konnte im Durchschnitt jeweils 3,0 Kühe an einem Termin decken. Der Preis je Konzeption lag zwischen 3 und 5 Birr. Die Non-Return-Rate (60-90 Tage), die Trächtigkeitsrate und die Kalberate lagen bei jeweils 85.62- 97.31%, 95.10% und 94.67%,

Das National Artificial Insemination Center besaß 50 Zuchtbullen, von denen 14 zur Samenproduktion eingesetzt wurden, die anderen waren Ersatzbullen. 64,1% der Besamungsbullen waren Friesen, die anderen gehörten zur Rasse Barka (14,3%) bzw. Waren Kreuzungen zwischen Arsi und Friesen (21,4%). Die jährliche Samenproduktion des Center in den Jahren 1995-1999 lag zwischen 23 580 und 103 440 Samenportionen. 2,77% bis 12,8% der Samenportionen wurden jährlich aus verschiedenen Gründen verworfen. Das Center gab 14 Birr (1,75 EUR) je Samenportion aus und verlangte 5 Birr je Konzeption in den städtischen Gebieten und 2 Birr je Konzeption auf dem Land. Die Durchschnittswerte für Spermavolumen, Spermiendichte, Motilität und Motilität nach dem Auftauen in den Jahren 1995-1999 lag jeweils zwischen 6,82-9.35 ml, 1.14-1.39x10 9 , 68.2-75.5% und 44-51%. Die Non-Return-Rate (60-90 Tage) nach der künstlichen Besamung lag zwischen 78% und 80%. Die Samenqualität wurde signifikant von Produktionsjahr und genetischer Gruppe der Bullen beeinflusst. Die Non-Return-Rate wurde signifikant vom Geschick der Besamungstechniker beeinflusst.

82,5-95% der Bauern im Gebiet Selale waren sich keiner Krankheit bewusst, die sich durch den Deckakt übertragen lässt. In Addis Abeba waren sich mehr als die Hälfte der
Bauern (60%) über Geschlechtskrankheiten im Klaren. Die Abortrate lag bei 2,5% im Gebiet Selale und bei 37,5% in Addis Abeba. Die meisten Aborte in Addis Abeba traten in den Großbetrieben auf (85,7%), gefolgt von den mittel großen (42,9%) und den Kleinbetrieben (23,1%). 80% der Aborte in Addis Abeba und alle Aborte im Gebiet Selale fanden vor dem letzten Drittel der Trächtigkeitsperiode statt. Was die Auftreten von Burcellose betrifft, so war das Ergebnis mit dem Rose-Bengal-Ringtest bei sämtlichen untersuchten Kühen und Bullen negativ.

acknowledgement.head: Acknowledgements
acknowledgement.p: I would like to express my earnest thanks and appreciation to my academic supervisor Prof. Dr. Kurt. J. Peters for his unreserved support and invaluable guidance in undertaking my PhD study. He had very great contributions in the inception, execution and refinement of this study. I would like also to give high regard for his concern and active involvement in my extracurricular affairs.

I am also very grateful to Prof. Dr. H. E. Jahnke, for his time and patience in reading, correcting and evaluating my dissertation and his involvement in the final oral examination. My deepest appreciation is also to Prof. Dr. H. Herzog for his willingness to chair the oral examination and his participation; and Prof. Dr. G. Seeland for his role as a member of the examination board.

It gives me a pleasure to acknowledge the concern and help I got from Frau Dr. B. Zumbach in data analyses and writing the dissertation. I would like also to appreciate her friendliness and kin interest to work with other people. I thank also Frau Dr. C. Kijora for her contributions and unreserved support throughout the course of this study. My sincere thanks also goes to other members of the Department of Tropical and Sub-tropical Animal Breeding and Acquaculture of the Humbouldt University of Berlin for their direct or indirect contributions to this study.

I appreciate the collaboration of the farmers at Selale and in Addis Ababa and the MOA personnel at the North-Western Shoa Zone of the Oromia Agricultural Office, the Addis Ababa Agricultural Office and the National Artificial Insemination Center. The encouragement and friendliness of my colleagues : Tadelle, Narinthon, Renate and Ademe is highly considerable.
My thanks goes also to KAAD (Katholischer Akademischer Ausländers-Dienst) for the financial support and institutional backing that enabled me to undertake my PhD study in Germany.
Finally, I am thankful for the love, understanding and patience of my wife, Selam Kinfe Demissie, throughout my study.
